Arterial.diagnosis: depends on the specific arterial condition and may involve imaging tests (such as angiography, ultrasound, or MRI), blood tests, physical examination

Acute Appendicitis.symptoms: abdominal pain (typically starting near the navel and migrating to the lower right abdomen), loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, abdominal swelling, constipation or diarrhea, inability to pass gas, abdominal tenderness (especially when pressure is applied)
Acute Appendicitis.precautions: seek prompt medical attention if symptoms occur, avoid taking pain relievers (such as ibuprofen or aspirin) without consulting a healthcare provider, avoid eating or drinking (to prevent worsening of symptoms)
Acute Appendicitis.drugs: intravenous antibiotics (such as ceftriaxone and metronidazole), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or morphine), surgery (appendectomy) to remove the inflamed appendix
Acute Appendicitis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, physical examination (including tests such as the rebound tenderness test), blood tests (such as white blood cell count), imaging tests (such as ultrasound or CT scan)

Bipolar Disorder.symptoms: mood swings (from mania to depression), elevated or irritable mood (mania), excessive energy, decreased need for sleep, rapid speech, racing thoughts, impulsivity, grandiose beliefs, depressive episodes with feelings of sadness, hopelessness, or worthlessness, loss of interest in activities
Bipolar Disorder.precautions: take medications as prescribed, attend therapy sessions regularly, maintain a consistent daily routine, get regular exercise, avoid alcohol and recreational drugs
Bipolar Disorder.drugs: mood stabilizers (such as lithium, valproate), antipsychotics, antidepressants (in combination with mood stabilizers)
Bipolar Disorder.diagnosis: psychiatric evaluation, mood charting, screening tests (such as the Mood Disorder Questionnaire)

Blepharitis.symptoms: redness and swelling of the eyelids, itching or burning sensation in the eyes, gritty or sticky sensation in the eyes, crusting or flakes on the eyelids (especially upon waking), sensitivity to light, blurred vision
Blepharitis.precautions: keep eyelids clean (with warm compresses and gentle eyelid scrubs), avoid rubbing or touching the eyes, avoid wearing eye makeup or contact lenses during flare-ups, use artificial tears to lubricate the eyes
Blepharitis.drugs: topical antibiotics (such as erythromycin or bacitracin), topical corticosteroids (for severe inflammation), eyelid hygiene products (such as eyelid scrubs or wipes)
Blepharitis.diagnosis: clinical examination, examination of the eyelids and eyelashes

Bruxism or teeth grinding.symptoms: grinding or clenching of teeth (often during sleep), worn tooth enamel, tooth sensitivity, jaw pain or tightness, headaches, facial pain, earache
Bruxism or teeth grinding.precautions: wear a mouthguard or splint at night to protect teeth, manage stress through relaxation techniques, avoid caffeine and alcohol before bedtime, maintain good sleep hygiene
Bruxism or teeth grinding.drugs: muscle relaxants (in severe cases), stress-reducing medications or techniques (such as antidepressants or cognitive-behavioral therapy)
Bruxism or teeth grinding.diagnosis: clinical examination, examination of teeth and jaw muscles

Barrett's esophagus.symptoms: often asymptomatic, but may include frequent heartburn, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, nausea, vomiting blood, unexplained weight loss
Barrett's esophagus.precautions: treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) to reduce the risk of Barrett's esophagus, avoid smoking, maintain a healthy weight, elevate the head of the bed to reduce nighttime reflux
Barrett's esophagus.drugs: acid-suppressing medications (proton pump inhibitors, H2-receptor antagonists), medications to strengthen the lower esophageal sphincter (baclofen)
Barrett's esophagus.diagnosis: upper endoscopy with biopsy, imaging tests (such as barium swallow or esophageal manometry)

Bile Duct Cancer.symptoms: jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), abdominal pain or discomfort, unexplained weight loss, itching, fever, nausea, vomiting, pale stools, dark urine
Bile Duct Cancer.precautions: manage risk factors (such as primary sclerosing cholangitis or chronic hepatitis), maintain a healthy weight, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, get regular medical check-ups
Bile Duct Cancer.drugs: chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy (such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors), surgery (if the cancer is operable)
Bile Duct Cancer.diagnosis: imaging tests (such as MRI, CT scan, or ultrasound), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), biopsy

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia.symptoms: frequent urination (especially at night), difficulty starting or maintaining urination, weak urine stream, dribbling at the end of urination, urinary urgency or hesitancy, incomplete bladder emptying, urinary retention, urinary tract infections
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia.precautions: avoid drinking fluids before bedtime, avoid caffeine and alcohol, practice double voiding (urinate, then wait a few minutes and try again), get regular exercise
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia.drugs: alpha blockers (such as tamsulosin), 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (such as finasteride), phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (such as tadalafil), combination therapy
Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia.diagnosis: digital rectal examination, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test, urinalysis, uroflowmetry

Burning Mouth Syndrome.symptoms: burning sensation in the mouth, tongue, lips, gums, or throat, dry mouth, metallic taste, tingling or numbness, altered taste perception, increased thirst, anxiety or depression
Burning Mouth Syndrome.precautions: avoid spicy, acidic, or hot foods and beverages, maintain good oral hygiene, avoid alcohol-based mouthwashes, manage stress, stay hydrated
Burning Mouth Syndrome.drugs: depends on the underlying cause and may include medications to manage pain (such as topical anesthetics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants), saliva substitutes or stimulants, treatment for underlying conditions (such as acid reflux or oral infections)
Burning Mouth Syndrome.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, medical history, oral examination (to rule out other oral conditions), tests to identify underlying causes (such as blood tests or allergy tests)

Bladder stones.symptoms: lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, painful urination, blood in the urine, difficulty urinating, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, urgency to urinate, pain in the penis or testicles (in men)
Bladder stones.precautions: stay hydrated, maintain a healthy diet (low in oxalate-rich foods such as spinach and nuts), avoid holding urine for long periods, seek prompt medical treatment for urinary tract infections
Bladder stones.drugs: depends on the size and composition of the stones, may include pain relievers, medications to dissolve certain types of stones (such as urinary alkalinizers or chelating agents), surgery (such as lithotripsy or cystoscopy) to remove larger stones
Bladder stones.diagnosis: urinalysis, imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, or X-ray), cystoscopy (to visualize the bladder and urinary tract)

Bone marrow failure syndrome.symptoms: depends on the specific type of bone marrow failure syndrome, may include fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, pale skin, frequent infections, easy bruising or bleeding, petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), unexplained fever
Bone marrow failure syndrome.precautions: seek prompt medical attention if symptoms occur, avoid exposure to infections, maintain good hygiene, avoid activities that may cause injury or bleeding, follow treatment plan as prescribed by healthcare provider
Bone marrow failure syndrome.drugs: depends on the underlying cause and may include medications to stimulate bone marrow function (such as growth factors), immunosuppressive therapy, blood transfusions, hematopoietic stem cell transplant
Bone marrow failure syndrome.diagnosis: complete blood count (CBC), bone marrow biopsy, blood tests (to check levels of blood cells and blood clotting factors), genetic testing (in certain cases)

Burns Injury.symptoms: depends on the severity of the burn (first-degree, second-degree, or third-degree), may include redness, swelling, pain, blistering, peeling skin, shock, difficulty breathing, carbon monoxide poisoning (if inhaled)
Burns Injury.precautions: cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for at least 10-20 minutes, cover the burn with a clean, dry cloth or sterile dressing, seek medical attention for severe burns or burns that cover a large area of the body
Burns Injury.drugs: depends on the severity of the burn and may include pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), topical antibiotics or burn creams, intravenous fluids (for severe burns), tetanus vaccination (if necessary)
Burns Injury.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, assessment of burn depth and extent, burn classification (such as Rule of Nines for estimating total body surface area affected)

Chlamydia Infection.symptoms: painful urination, unusual discharge from the penis or vagina, pain during sexual intercourse, abdominal pain (in women), pain or swelling in the testicles (in men), rectal pain, discharge, or bleeding (if contracted through anal sex)
Chlamydia Infection.precautions: practice safe sex (use condoms), limit sexual partners, get tested regularly for sexually transmitted infections, avoid sexual contact if diagnosed with chlamydia until treatment is completed
Chlamydia Infection.drugs: antibiotics (such as azithromycin or doxycycline), partners should also be treated to prevent reinfection
Chlamydia Infection.diagnosis: urine test, swab test from the urethra (in men) or cervix (in women), rectal or throat swab (if indicated)

Crohn's Disease.symptoms: abdominal pain and cramping, diarrhea (often bloody), weight loss, fatigue, fever, reduced appetite, perianal fistulas or abscesses, mouth sores, nausea and vomiting, joint pain or swelling
Crohn's Disease.precautions: follow treatment plan as prescribed by healthcare provider, maintain a healthy diet (avoiding trigger foods), stay hydrated, manage stress, get regular medical check-ups
Crohn's Disease.drugs: anti-inflammatory drugs (such as corticosteroids or mesalamine), immunosuppressants (such as azathioprine or methotrexate), biologic therapies (such as infliximab or adalimumab)
Crohn's Disease.diagnosis: physical examination, colonoscopy, imaging tests (such as MRI or CT scan), blood tests (to check for signs of inflammation or anemia)

Cystic Fibrosis.symptoms: persistent cough with thick mucus, wheezing, frequent lung infections (such as pneumonia or bronchitis), poor growth or weight gain, salty-tasting skin, persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain or bloating, difficulty breathing, infertility (in males)
Cystic Fibrosis.precautions: follow treatment plan as prescribed by healthcare provider, maintain good lung health (including regular airway clearance techniques), eat a high-calorie, high-fat diet, stay hydrated, avoid smoke and other lung irritants
Cystic Fibrosis.drugs: mucolytics (such as dornase alfa), bronchodilators (such as albuterol), antibiotics (to treat lung infections), pancreatic enzyme supplements (to aid digestion), CFTR modulator therapies (such as ivacaftor or lumacaftor)
Cystic Fibrosis.diagnosis: newborn screening (for infants), sweat test, genetic testing, lung function tests

Cystitis.symptoms: urinary urgency, frequent urination, burning or pain during urination, cloudy or strong-smelling urine, pelvic discomfort or pressure, blood in the urine (hematuria), low-grade fever, fatigue
Cystitis.precautions: drink plenty of water, urinate frequently and completely, practice good hygiene (wipe from front to back after using the bathroom), avoid irritants (such as caffeine, alcohol, and spicy foods), wear cotton underwear
Cystitis.drugs: antibiotics (such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, nitrofurantoin, or ciprofloxacin), urinary analgesics (such as phenazopyridine, for pain relief)
Cystitis.diagnosis: urinalysis, urine culture and sensitivity testing, pelvic exam (in women), imaging tests (such as ultrasound or CT scan, if recurrent or complicated)

Cirrhosis.symptoms: fatigue, weakness, easy bruising, yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice), loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, abdominal swelling (ascites), itching, spider-like blood vessels on the skin (spider angiomas), dark urine
Cirrhosis.precautions: avoid alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet, avoid medications that can cause liver damage, get vaccinated for hepatitis A and B
Cirrhosis.drugs: depends on the underlying cause and complications, may include diuretics (to reduce fluid buildup), beta-blockers (to reduce risk of bleeding from varices), medications to manage specific symptoms (such as itching or fatigue)
Cirrhosis.diagnosis: blood tests (liver function tests, hepatitis markers), imaging tests (ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), liver biopsy

Carpal Tunnel.symptoms: pain, numbness, and tingling in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, weakness or clumsiness in the hand, pain or tingling that worsens at night, difficulty gripping objects, shock-like sensations that radiate into the fingers or up the arm
Carpal Tunnel.precautions: take frequent breaks from repetitive hand activities, maintain a neutral wrist position when typing or using tools, use ergonomic equipment, perform stretching exercises for the hands and wrists, wear wrist splints at night
Carpal Tunnel.drugs: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroid injections, pain relievers, diuretics (to reduce swelling), anticonvulsants (for nerve pain)
Carpal Tunnel.diagnosis: clinical examination, nerve conduction studies, electromyography (EMG), imaging tests (such as MRI)

Cervical Spondylosis.symptoms: neck pain and stiffness, headaches (typically at the back of the head), shoulder pain, numbness or weakness in the arms or hands, difficulty walking or maintaining balance, muscle spasms, reduced range of motion in the neck
Cervical Spondylosis.precautions: maintain good posture, perform neck exercises to strengthen muscles and improve flexibility, take breaks from prolonged sitting or standing, use proper ergonomics at work, avoid activities that strain the neck
Cervical Spondylosis.drugs: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), muscle relaxants, analgesics (pain relievers), corticosteroid injections, anticonvulsants (for nerve pain)
Cervical Spondylosis.diagnosis: clinical examination, imaging tests (X-rays, CT scan, MRI), electromyography (EMG)

Celiac Disease.symptoms: digestive symptoms (such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, constipation), fatigue, weight loss, anemia, osteoporosis, dermatitis herpetiformis (itchy skin rash), mouth ulcers, joint pain, infertility, delayed growth (in children)
Celiac Disease.precautions: follow a strict gluten-free diet for life, read food labels carefully, avoid cross-contamination with gluten-containing foods, get regular check-ups with a healthcare provider, consider working with a dietitian
Celiac Disease.drugs: there are no medications to treat celiac disease, but medications may be prescribed to manage symptoms (such as antidiarrheals, corticosteroids, or supplements for nutritional deficiencies)
Celiac Disease.diagnosis: blood tests (to check for antibodies to gluten), intestinal biopsy, genetic testing

Cardiomyopathy.symptoms: shortness of breath (especially during physical activity or when lying flat), fatigue, swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet (edema), coughing, chest pain or discomfort, irregular heartbeats (arrhythmias), dizziness or lightheadedness, fainting
Cardiomyopathy.precautions: avoid alcohol consumption, follow a heart-healthy diet (low in salt and saturated fats), get regular exercise (as recommended by healthcare provider), manage stress, take medications as prescribed
Cardiomyopathy.drugs: depends on the type and severity of cardiomyopathy, may include ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, diuretics, anticoagulants, antiarrhythmic medications, or other drugs to manage symptoms and complications
Cardiomyopathy.diagnosis: physical examination, imaging tests (echocardiogram, MRI, CT scan), electrocardiogram (ECG), cardiac catheterization

Cholera.symptoms: sudden onset of watery diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration (which can lead to rapid heart rate, low blood pressure, dry mucous membranes, sunken eyes, decreased urine output), muscle cramps, shock
Cholera.precautions: practice good hygiene (especially handwashing with soap and water), drink clean, safe water, avoid eating raw or undercooked food, avoid street food and unpeeled fruits and vegetables in endemic areas, get vaccinated (if traveling to high-risk areas)
Cholera.drugs: oral rehydration solution (to replace lost fluids and electrolytes), antibiotics (such as doxycycline or azithromycin for severe cases), intravenous fluids (for severe dehydration)
Cholera.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, stool culture (to detect presence of Vibrio cholerae bacteria), rapid diagnostic tests

Cataract.symptoms: cloudy or blurry vision, faded colors, glare (especially at night or in bright sunlight), double vision in one eye, frequent changes in eyeglass or contact lens prescription, difficulty seeing at night
Cataract.precautions: protect eyes from ultraviolet (UV) radiation with sunglasses or hats, quit smoking, manage chronic health conditions (such as diabetes), get regular eye exams, eat a balanced diet rich in antioxidants
Cataract.drugs: there are no medications to treat cataracts, surgery (phacoemulsification or extracapsular extraction) to remove the cloudy lens and replace it with an artificial lens
Cataract.diagnosis: comprehensive eye examination, visual acuity test, slit-lamp examination (to examine the lens), dilated eye exam

Cervicitis.symptoms: may not cause symptoms in some cases, abnormal vaginal discharge (yellowish or greenish, with an unpleasant odor), vaginal bleeding (after intercourse or between periods), pelvic pain or discomfort, painful urination, pain during intercourse
Cervicitis.precautions: practice safe sex (use condoms), get regular pelvic exams and Pap tests (as recommended by healthcare provider), seek prompt medical attention for symptoms of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
Cervicitis.drugs: depends on the underlying cause (such as bacterial infection or STI), may include antibiotics (such as azithromycin or doxycycline), antiviral medications (for viral infections)
Cervicitis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, pelvic examination (to inspect the cervix), tests for sexually transmitted infections (such as chlamydia or gonorrhea), Pap test (to rule out cervical cancer)

Chicken Pox.symptoms: itchy rash that usually starts on the face, chest, or back and spreads to other parts of the body, fluid-filled blisters that break open and crust over, fever, headache, fatigue, loss of appetite, muscle or joint pain
Chicken Pox.precautions: get vaccinated (varicella vaccine), practice good hygiene (especially handwashing), avoid contact with individuals who have chickenpox or shingles, avoid scratching the rash to prevent infection and scarring
Chicken Pox.drugs: antiviral medications (such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir), over-the-counter pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), antihistamines (for itching)
Chicken Pox.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, characteristic appearance of the rash, laboratory tests (such as viral culture or polymerase chain reaction)

Cholangitis.symptoms: right upper abdominal pain, fever, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), nausea, vomiting, clay-colored stools, dark urine, itching, confusion or lethargy (in severe cases)
Cholangitis.precautions: seek prompt medical attention if symptoms occur, complete prescribed course of antibiotics, maintain good hydration, follow a low-fat diet, avoid alcohol
Cholangitis.drugs: antibiotics (such as ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, or third-generation cephalosporins), intravenous fluids (for hydration), pain relievers
Cholangitis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (such as liver function tests), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

Cleft Lip And Palate.symptoms: visible split or gap in the lip and/or roof of the mouth (palate), difficulty feeding (for infants with cleft lip and/or palate), nasal speech, frequent ear infections, dental problems (such as misaligned teeth), speech and language delays
Cleft Lip And Palate.precautions: early intervention with surgical correction (usually in infancy), specialized feeding techniques for infants with cleft lip and/or palate, regular dental check-ups and orthodontic treatment as needed, speech therapy to address speech and language delays
Cleft Lip And Palate.drugs: not applicable for the treatment of cleft lip and palate, but medications may be prescribed to manage associated conditions or symptoms (such as antibiotics for ear infections)
Cleft Lip And Palate.diagnosis: visual examination of the mouth and palate, prenatal ultrasound (to detect cleft lip and/or palate during pregnancy), imaging tests (such as CT scan or MRI)

Cushing's syndrome.symptoms: weight gain (especially in the upper body and face), rounding of the face (moon face), thinning skin that bruises easily, purple stretch marks (striae) on the abdomen, arms, or thighs, muscle weakness, fatigue, high blood pressure, irregular menstruation (in women), decreased libido (in men)
Cushing's syndrome.precautions: treatment of the underlying cause (such as tapering off corticosteroid medications), lifestyle modifications (such as regular exercise and a balanced diet), regular medical follow-up and monitoring
Cushing's syndrome.drugs: depends on the underlying cause and may include surgery (to remove tumors or lesions), medications to reduce cortisol production (such as ketoconazole or metyrapone), pituitary radiotherapy
Cushing's syndrome.diagnosis: hormone tests (such as cortisol level measurements), imaging tests (such as CT scan or MRI), dexamethasone suppression test

Diabetes.symptoms: increased thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, blurred vision, slow-healing sores or infections, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, recurrent yeast infections
Diabetes.precautions: monitor blood sugar levels regularly, adhere to a healthy diet and exercise regimen, take medications (such as insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents) as prescribed, manage stress, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Diabetes.drugs: depends on the type of diabetes and may include insulin therapy, oral medications (such as metformin or sulfonylureas), other injectable medications (such as GLP-1 receptor agonists or SGLT2 inhibitors)
Diabetes.diagnosis: blood tests (such as fasting blood glucose, oral glucose tolerance test, or HbA1c), urine tests (to check for glucose and ketones), glycemic control monitoring

Diarrhea.symptoms: frequent loose or watery stools, abdominal cramps, bloating, nausea, vomiting, fever, dehydration (signs of dehydration include dry mouth, dark urine, decreased urine output, lethargy)
Diarrhea.precautions: stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, consume bland or easily digestible foods (such as bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast), avoid dairy products, caffeine, alcohol, and high-fat or spicy foods, practice good hygiene (especially handwashing)
Diarrhea.drugs: oral rehydration solutions (to replace lost fluids and electrolytes), antibiotics (if diarrhea is caused by a bacterial infection), antidiarrheal medications (such as loperamide) for short-term relief of symptoms
Diarrhea.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, stool tests (to identify the cause of diarrhea, such as bacteria, parasites, or viruses)

Down Syndrome.symptoms: distinct facial features (such as almond-shaped eyes, small ears, and a flat nasal bridge), developmental delays (including cognitive and motor skills), intellectual disability, low muscle tone (hypotonia), short stature, congenital heart defects, gastrointestinal abnormalities
Down Syndrome.precautions: early intervention programs (such as physical therapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy), regular medical check-ups and screenings (including cardiac evaluations), support services for individuals and families, inclusive education programs
Down Syndrome.drugs: depends on associated conditions and symptoms, may include medications to manage congenital heart defects, thyroid disorders, or behavioral issues
Down Syndrome.diagnosis: chromosomal analysis (such as karyotype testing) to confirm the presence of an extra chromosome 21, prenatal screening tests (such as ultrasound or blood tests)

Diverticulosis.symptoms: often asymptomatic, but may include abdominal pain (usually in the lower left side), bloating, changes in bowel habits (constipation or diarrhea), rectal bleeding (bright red blood in stool), fever (if diverticulitis develops)
Diverticulosis.precautions: consume a high-fiber diet to prevent constipation and promote regular bowel movements, drink plenty of fluids, exercise regularly, avoid straining during bowel movements, seek medical attention for any concerning symptoms
Diverticulosis.drugs: often not applicable for diverticulosis, treatment may include pain relievers or antispasmodic medications to manage symptoms, antibiotics (if diverticulitis develops)
Diverticulosis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, imaging tests (such as CT scan or colonoscopy), stool tests (to rule out other causes of gastrointestinal bleeding)

Dengue.symptoms: sudden high fever, severe headaches, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, skin rash (often with small red or purple spots), mild bleeding (such as nosebleeds or gum bleeding)
Dengue.precautions: prevent mosquito bites by using insect repellent, wearing long-sleeved shirts and long pants, and using screens or nets on windows and doors, eliminate mosquito breeding sites (such as standing water), seek medical attention if symptoms of dengue develop
Dengue.drugs: symptomatic treatment to relieve pain and fever (such as acetaminophen), intravenous fluids (for severe cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome)
Dengue.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (such as NS1 antigen test or IgM and IgG antibody tests)

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.symptoms: muscle weakness (usually starting in the legs and pelvis), difficulty walking or running, frequent falls, progressive difficulty standing up from a lying or sitting position, enlarged calf muscles (pseudohypertrophy), muscle contractures, delayed motor milestones (such as sitting and walking), learning disabilities (in some cases)
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.precautions: regular medical check-ups and monitoring of muscle function, physical therapy to maintain muscle strength and flexibility, assistive devices (such as braces or wheelchairs) as needed, genetic counseling for family planning
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.drugs: corticosteroids (such as prednisone) to slow the progression of muscle weakness, medications to manage symptoms (such as pain relievers or heart medications), investigational therapies targeting the underlying genetic cause
Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, muscle biopsy (to assess muscle tissue), genetic testing (to identify mutations in the DMD gene)

Diabetes Insipidus.symptoms: excessive thirst, excessive urination (especially at night), diluted urine (pale in color), dehydration, fatigue, irritability, dry skin, fever (if associated with certain causes of diabetes insipidus)
Diabetes Insipidus.precautions: ensure adequate fluid intake to prevent dehydration, monitor urine output and color, avoid excessive intake of caffeine or alcohol, wear medical alert identification, seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or if fever develops
Diabetes Insipidus.drugs: depends on the underlying cause, may include desmopressin (to replace vasopressin), thiazide diuretics (to reduce urine output), medications to treat underlying conditions (such as surgery or radiation therapy for pituitary tumors)
Diabetes Insipidus.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, water deprivation test, urine and blood tests (to measure electrolyte levels and urine concentration)

Diphtheria.symptoms: sore throat, fever, swollen glands (lymph nodes) in the neck, difficulty breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, bluish skin coloration, cough, nasal discharge, fatigue, malaise
Diphtheria.precautions: vaccination with the diphtheria vaccine (part of the DTaP or Tdap vaccine series), practice good hygiene (such as handwashing), avoid close contact with infected individuals, seek medical attention if symptoms of diphtheria develop
Diphtheria.drugs: antibiotics (such as erythromycin or penicillin) to treat the bacterial infection, antitoxin (to neutralize the diphtheria toxin)
Diphtheria.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, laboratory tests (throat culture or polymerase chain reaction test)

Dextrocardia Situs Inversus.symptoms: may vary depending on associated congenital heart defects, often asymptomatic if there are no other heart abnormalities, symptoms of associated heart defects may include chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, palpitations, fainting
Dextrocardia Situs Inversus.precautions: regular medical check-ups to monitor heart function, genetic counseling for family planning, follow treatment plan as prescribed by healthcare provider
Dextrocardia Situs Inversus.drugs: depends on associated heart defects, may include medications to manage symptoms or prevent complications (such as blood thinners or medications to control heart rhythm)
Dextrocardia Situs Inversus.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, imaging tests (such as echocardiography, electrocardiogram, or chest X-ray)

Diabetic Neuropathy.symptoms: numbness, tingling, or pain in the hands, arms, feet, or legs, sharp or burning pain, sensitivity to touch, muscle weakness, problems with coordination, digestive issues, urinary problems, changes in blood pressure or heart rate
Diabetic Neuropathy.precautions: maintain tight control of blood sugar levels, inspect feet daily for any signs of injury or infection, wear comfortable shoes, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy lifestyle
Diabetic Neuropathy.drugs: medications to relieve pain (such as antidepressants, anticonvulsants, or opioids), topical treatments (such as capsaicin cream), physical therapy, acupuncture
Diabetic Neuropathy.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, nerve function tests (such as electromyography or nerve conduction studies), blood tests (to check blood sugar levels)

Diabetic Retinopathy.symptoms: may initially be asymptomatic, symptoms may develop as the condition progresses and may include blurry or distorted vision, floaters (spots or dark strings floating in the field of vision), difficulty perceiving colors, fluctuating vision, vision loss
Diabetic Retinopathy.precautions: maintain tight control of blood sugar levels, undergo regular eye exams (at least once a year or as recommended by healthcare provider), manage blood pressure and cholesterol levels, avoid smoking
Diabetic Retinopathy.drugs: depends on the stage and severity of diabetic retinopathy, may include medications to control blood sugar, injections of anti-VEGF medications or corticosteroids into the eye, laser surgery, vitrectomy
Diabetic Retinopathy.diagnosis: eye examination (including dilation of the pupils), retinal photography, fluorescein angiography, optical coherence tomography (OCT)

Encephalitis.symptoms: headache, fever, confusion or altered mental status, seizures, hallucinations, personality changes, weakness or paralysis, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, loss of consciousness, coma
Encephalitis.precautions: get vaccinated against viruses that can cause encephalitis (such as measles, mumps, and Japanese encephalitis), practice good hygiene, avoid mosquito bites (in areas where mosquito-borne viruses are prevalent)
Encephalitis.drugs: antiviral medications (if encephalitis is caused by a virus), corticosteroids (to reduce brain swelling and inflammation), supportive care (such as intravenous fluids and anticonvulsants)
Encephalitis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, neurological examination, imaging tests (such as CT scan or MRI), lumbar puncture (to analyze cerebrospinal fluid)

Emphysema.symptoms: shortness of breath (especially during physical activities), chronic cough, wheezing, chest tightness, fatigue, weight loss, barrel-shaped chest, pursed-lip breathing, frequent respiratory infections
Emphysema.precautions: quit smoking and avoid exposure to secondhand smoke, avoid air pollutants (such as dust or fumes), get vaccinated against respiratory infections (such as influenza and pneumonia), participate in pulmonary rehabilitation programs
Emphysema.drugs: bronchodilators (such as albuterol or ipratropium), inhaled corticosteroids, supplemental oxygen therapy, antibiotics (for treating respiratory infections)
Emphysema.diagnosis: spirometry, chest X-ray or CT scan, arterial blood gas test, physical examination

Ear Infection.symptoms: ear pain or discomfort (especially when lying down), hearing loss, drainage from the ear, feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear, fever, irritability (in infants and young children), difficulty sleeping
Ear Infection.precautions: practice good hygiene (such as regular handwashing), avoid smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke, get vaccinated against diseases that can cause ear infections (such as influenza and pneumococcal disease)
Ear Infection.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), ear drops containing antibiotics or steroids (for bacterial infections), decongestants (for ear infections related to allergies or colds)
Ear Infection.diagnosis: physical examination, otoscopy (to examine the ear canal and eardrum), tympanometry (to measure middle ear function), culture of ear fluid (if drainage is present)

Epididymitis.symptoms: pain or discomfort in the scrotum (often on one side), swelling or tenderness of the testicle, redness or warmth of the scrotum, pain or burning sensation during urination, discharge from the penis, fever, chills
Epididymitis.precautions: practice safe sex, maintain good hygiene, avoid holding urine for long periods, avoid activities that may cause injury to the genital area
Epididymitis.drugs: antibiotics (such as ciprofloxacin, doxycycline, or azithromycin), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), supportive measures (such as rest, elevation of the scrotum)
Epididymitis.diagnosis: physical examination, ultrasound of the scrotum, urine tests (to check for signs of infection)

Esophagitis.symptoms: difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), painful swallowing (odynophagia), chest pain, heartburn, acid reflux, regurgitation of food or sour liquid, sensation of a lump in the throat, nausea, vomiting, cough
Esophagitis.precautions: avoid triggers that worsen symptoms (such as spicy foods, acidic foods, or alcohol), eat smaller meals, avoid lying down after eating, elevate the head of the bed, quit smoking
Esophagitis.drugs: proton pump inhibitors (such as omeprazole or pantoprazole), H2-receptor antagonists (such as ranitidine or famotidine), antacids
Esophagitis.diagnosis: upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy), biopsy (to confirm inflammation or tissue damage), barium swallow test, esophageal pH monitoring

Ectopic Pregnancy.symptoms: abdominal or pelvic pain (often sharp and on one side), vaginal bleeding, shoulder pain, dizziness or fainting, low blood pressure, pain with urination or bowel movements (if ruptured), signs of shock (rapid heartbeat, pale skin, sweating)
Ectopic Pregnancy.precautions: seek immediate medical attention if experiencing symptoms of ectopic pregnancy, avoid smoking and alcohol consumption, use contraception consistently and correctly to prevent unintended pregnancies
Ectopic Pregnancy.drugs: methotrexate (for non-ruptured ectopic pregnancies), surgery (laparoscopy or laparotomy) to remove the ectopic pregnancy and repair any damage
Ectopic Pregnancy.diagnosis: pelvic exam, transvaginal ultrasound, blood tests (to measure levels of human chorionic gonadotropin)

Endocarditis.symptoms: fever, chills, fatigue, weakness, night sweats, shortness of breath, new or worsening heart murmurs, chest pain, cough, unexplained weight loss, skin rash or small spots under the skin
Endocarditis.precautions: maintain good oral hygiene, seek prompt treatment for infections, practice safe injection practices, avoid sharing needles or other drug paraphernalia, inform healthcare providers of any history of heart valve disease
Endocarditis.drugs: antibiotics (intravenous antibiotics for several weeks), antifungal medications (if fungal endocarditis is suspected), surgery to repair or replace damaged heart valves (in severe cases)
Endocarditis.diagnosis: blood cultures (to identify the causative organism), echocardiogram (transthoracic or transesophageal), chest X-ray, electrocardiogram (ECG)

Fibromyalgia.symptoms: widespread muscle pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances (such as insomnia or non-restorative sleep), cognitive difficulties (such as memory problems or difficulty concentrating), headaches, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) symptoms, anxiety, depression
Fibromyalgia.precautions: get regular exercise (such as low-impact activities like walking or swimming), maintain a regular sleep schedule, practice stress-reduction techniques (such as mindfulness or meditation), eat a balanced diet, pace yourself and avoid overexertion
Fibromyalgia.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or NSAIDs), antidepressants (such as duloxetine or amitriptyline), anticonvulsants (such as pregabalin), muscle relaxants
Fibromyalgia.diagnosis: based on symptoms and medical history, exclusion of other possible causes of symptoms, tender points examination (although this is no longer a requirement for diagnosis)

Fungal Infection.symptoms: vary depending on the type and location of the infection, may include redness, itching, rash, blisters, scaling or peeling skin, pain or discomfort, discolored or thickened nails, vaginal discharge (in case of vaginal yeast infection)
Fungal Infection.precautions: practice good hygiene, keep skin clean and dry, avoid sharing personal items (such as towels or clothing), avoid walking barefoot in public areas (to prevent fungal foot infections), wear breathable fabrics
Fungal Infection.drugs: antifungal medications (topical creams, ointments, or powders for skin infections, oral antifungal medications for systemic infections), antifungal shampoos or creams (for fungal scalp infections)
Fungal Infection.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, microscopy (to identify fungi under a microscope), fungal culture (to confirm the presence of fungi and identify the species), skin biopsy (in certain cases)

Folic acid deficiency.symptoms: fatigue, weakness, pale skin (pallor), shortness of breath, irritability, mouth sores, swollen tongue, poor growth (in children), changes in mood, memory problems
Folic acid deficiency.precautions: consume foods rich in folate (such as leafy greens, citrus fruits, beans, fortified grains), consider taking folic acid supplements (especially during pregnancy or for individuals at risk of deficiency), avoid excessive alcohol consumption
Folic acid deficiency.drugs: folic acid supplements (usually in the form of oral tablets or capsules), treatment of underlying conditions that may contribute to deficiency (such as malabsorption disorders)
Folic acid deficiency.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure levels of folate), assessment of dietary intake and potential risk factors for deficiency

Gastroenteritis.symptoms: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain or cramping, fever, headache, muscle aches, dehydration (dry mouth, decreased urine output, dizziness), loss of appetite, fatigue
Gastroenteritis.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, drink clean and safe water, avoid consuming undercooked or contaminated food, wash fruits and vegetables thoroughly, avoid close contact with infected individuals
Gastroenteritis.drugs: oral rehydration solutions (ORS), antiemetics (such as ondansetron for severe nausea), antidiarrheal medications (such as loperamide for adults), antibiotics (only if bacterial infection is confirmed), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen)
Gastroenteritis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, stool tests (to identify causative organisms), blood tests (in severe cases or to check for dehydration), rapid antigen tests (for specific pathogens like rotavirus)

Glaucoma.symptoms: often asymptomatic in early stages, gradual loss of peripheral vision, tunnel vision (in advanced stages), eye pain, redness in the eye, halos around lights, blurred vision, headache, nausea and vomiting (in acute angle-closure glaucoma)
Glaucoma.precautions: regular eye exams, especially if at high risk, manage underlying health conditions (such as diabetes or high blood pressure), avoid smoking, maintain a healthy lifestyle (including regular exercise and a balanced diet)
Glaucoma.drugs: eye drops to lower intraocular pressure (such as prostaglandin analogs, beta blockers, alpha agonists), oral medications (such as carbonic anhydrase inhibitors), laser therapy (such as trabeculoplasty), surgery (such as trabeculectomy or drainage implants)
Glaucoma.diagnosis: comprehensive eye exam, tonometry (to measure intraocular pressure), ophthalmoscopy (to examine the optic nerve), visual field test, gonioscopy (to inspect the drainage angle), pachymetry (to measure corneal thickness)

GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease).symptoms: heartburn (a burning sensation in the chest), regurgitation of food or sour liquid, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), chest pain, chronic cough, sore throat, hoarseness, sensation of a lump in the throat, nausea, burping
GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease).precautions: eat smaller meals, avoid lying down immediately after eating, elevate the head of the bed, avoid foods and beverages that trigger symptoms (such as spicy foods, alcohol, caffeine), quit smoking, maintain a healthy weight
GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease).drugs: antacids, H2-receptor antagonists (such as ranitidine or famotidine), proton pump inhibitors (such as omeprazole or esomeprazole), prokinetic agents (to help clear stomach contents more quickly), alginates (to form a barrier preventing acid reflux)
GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease).diagnosis: clinical evaluation, upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy), pH monitoring (to measure acid levels in the esophagus), esophageal manometry (to assess esophageal motility), barium swallow test

Gout.symptoms: sudden and severe joint pain (commonly in the big toe), joint swelling, redness and warmth over the affected joint, limited range of motion, lingering discomfort after the severe pain subsides, tophi (deposits of uric acid crystals under the skin)
Gout.precautions: maintain a healthy weight, avoid foods high in purines (such as red meat, seafood, organ meats), limit alcohol consumption, stay hydrated, avoid sugary drinks, manage chronic conditions (such as hypertension or diabetes)
Gout.drugs: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs such as ibuprofen or naproxen), colchicine, corticosteroids (oral or injected), medications to lower uric acid levels (such as allopurinol or febuxostat), uricosurics (to increase uric acid excretion)
Gout.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, joint fluid test (to detect urate crystals), blood tests (to measure uric acid levels), X-ray imaging, ultrasound (to detect urate crystal deposits), dual-energy CT scan

Gingivitis.symptoms: red, swollen gums, bleeding gums (especially when brushing or flossing), bad breath, receding gums, tender gums, soft gums, gums that feel sensitive to touch, changes in the way teeth fit together
Gingivitis.precautions: maintain good oral hygiene (brushing twice a day and flossing daily), regular dental check-ups and cleanings, avoid tobacco use, eat a balanced diet, manage conditions that increase risk (such as diabetes)
Gingivitis.drugs: antiseptic mouthwashes (such as chlorhexidine), prescription-strength toothpaste (with higher fluoride content), antibiotics (for severe cases or underlying infections), pain relievers (such as ibuprofen)
Gingivitis.diagnosis: dental examination, assessment of plaque and tartar buildup, measurement of gum pockets (periodontal probing), dental X-rays (to check for bone loss)

Gastrointestinal.symptoms: varies widely depending on the specific gastrointestinal condition, common symptoms include abdominal pain or cramping, bloating, diarrhea, constipation, nausea, vomiting, gas, heartburn, blood in the stool
Gastrointestinal.precautions: maintain a healthy diet (high in fiber, low in processed foods), stay hydrated, exercise regularly, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, manage stress
Gastrointestinal.drugs: depends on the specific condition, may include antacids, proton pump inhibitors, H2-receptor antagonists, antiemetics, antidiarrheal medications, laxatives, antibiotics (for bacterial infections), anti-inflammatory drugs (for conditions like IBD)
Gastrointestinal.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests, stool tests, imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), endoscopy (upper or lower gastrointestinal endoscopy)

Gastroparesis.symptoms: nausea, vomiting (especially of undigested food), feeling full quickly when eating, bloating, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, weight loss, malnutrition, heartburn, fluctuations in blood sugar levels
Gastroparesis.precautions: eat smaller, more frequent meals, avoid high-fat and high-fiber foods, chew food thoroughly, stay upright after eating, manage blood sugar levels if diabetic, avoid carbonated beverages
Gastroparesis.drugs: prokinetic agents (such as metoclopramide or erythromycin), antiemetic medications (such as ondansetron or promethazine), medications to manage pain (such as tricyclic antidepressants for neuropathic pain), nutritional support (such as feeding tubes in severe cases)
Gastroparesis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, gastric emptying study, upper endoscopy, ultrasound, blood tests (to rule out other conditions), breath tests (to measure stomach emptying)

Gangrene.symptoms: discoloration of the affected area (red, then brown or black), severe pain followed by numbness, foul-smelling discharge, swelling, blisters, fever, skin breakdown or ulcers
Gangrene.precautions: maintain good hygiene, manage chronic conditions (such as diabetes), avoid smoking, ensure proper wound care, seek prompt medical attention for infections or injuries
Gangrene.drugs: antibiotics (for infection), pain relievers, anticoagulants (to improve blood flow), hyperbaric oxygen therapy, surgical removal of dead tissue (debridement), amputation (in severe cases)
Gangrene.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, imaging tests (such as X-rays, CT scans, or MRI), blood tests, tissue cultures (to identify causative organisms), arteriogram (to assess blood flow)

Genital Warts.symptoms: small, flesh-colored or gray growths in the genital area, itching or discomfort, bleeding with intercourse, cauliflower-shaped clusters of warts, warts that are flat, raised, or pedunculated
Genital Warts.precautions: use condoms during sexual activity, get vaccinated against HPV, avoid sexual contact with infected individuals, maintain good genital hygiene, undergo regular screening
Genital Warts.drugs: topical treatments (such as imiquimod, podophyllin, or sinecatechins), cryotherapy (freezing warts), surgical removal, electrocautery (burning off warts), laser treatment
Genital Warts.diagnosis: visual examination, biopsy (if diagnosis is uncertain), HPV DNA test (to identify the presence of high-risk HPV types)

Graves Disease.symptoms: anxiety, irritability, tremors, heat intolerance, weight loss despite increased appetite, enlarged thyroid gland (goiter), bulging eyes (exophthalmos), rapid or irregular heartbeat, sweating, fatigue, muscle weakness
Graves Disease.precautions: regular monitoring and follow-up with a healthcare provider, avoid smoking, manage stress, maintain a balanced diet, avoid excessive iodine intake
Graves Disease.drugs: antithyroid medications (such as methimazole or propylthiouracil), beta-blockers (to manage symptoms like rapid heartbeat), radioactive iodine therapy, surgery (thyroidectomy)
Graves Disease.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure levels of thyroid hormones and TSH), radioactive iodine uptake test, thyroid scan, ultrasound, physical examination

Giardiasis.symptoms: diarrhea, gas, greasy stools that tend to float, stomach cramps or pain, nausea, dehydration, weight loss, fatigue, bloating, loss of appetite
Giardiasis.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, drink clean and safe water, avoid consuming untreated water from lakes or streams, wash fruits and vegetables thoroughly, avoid close contact with infected individuals
Giardiasis.drugs: antiparasitic medications (such as metronidazole, tinidazole, or nitazoxanide), rehydration solutions, supportive care (such as rest and adequate fluid intake)
Giardiasis.diagnosis: stool tests (to detect the presence of Giardia parasites), antigen tests (to identify Giardia proteins in stool), stool culture, PCR tests

Glomerulonephritis.symptoms: pink or cola-colored urine (hematuria), foamy urine (due to proteinuria), high blood pressure, swelling in the face, hands, feet, or abdomen (edema), fatigue, decreased urine output, shortness of breath
Glomerulonephritis.precautions: manage underlying conditions (such as diabetes or high blood pressure), avoid nephrotoxic substances (such as NSAIDs and certain antibiotics), maintain a healthy diet low in salt and protein, stay hydrated, avoid infections
Glomerulonephritis.drugs: immunosuppressive medications (such as corticosteroids or cyclophosphamide), blood pressure medications (such as ACE inhibitors or ARBs), diuretics, antibiotics (if infection is present), dialysis (in severe cases)
Glomerulonephritis.diagnosis: urinalysis, blood tests (to assess kidney function and detect antibodies), kidney biopsy, imaging tests (such as ultrasound or CT scan), serological tests

Gonorrhea.symptoms: painful urination, increased vaginal or penile discharge, vaginal bleeding between periods, pain or swelling in one testicle, pelvic or abdominal pain, anal itching or discharge, sore throat (if oral infection)
Gonorrhea.precautions: use condoms during sexual activity, undergo regular screening, avoid sexual contact with infected individuals, disclose STI status to sexual partners, practice safe sex
Gonorrhea.drugs: antibiotics (such as ceftriaxone and azithromycin), pain relievers (for symptom management), follow-up testing to ensure infection is cleared
Gonorrhea.diagnosis: nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT), culture test, urine test, swab test from affected areas (such as urethra, cervix, rectum, or throat)

Goiter.symptoms: visible swelling at the base of the neck, tightness in the throat, difficulty swallowing, difficulty breathing, coughing, hoarseness, hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism symptoms (depending on cause)
Goiter.precautions: ensure adequate iodine intake (through diet or supplements), avoid goitrogenic foods (in excessive amounts), manage underlying thyroid conditions, regular monitoring of thyroid function, avoid smoking
Goiter.drugs: thyroid hormone replacement therapy (for hypothyroidism), antithyroid medications (for hyperthyroidism), iodine supplements (for iodine deficiency), surgery (for large or symptomatic goiters), radioactive iodine therapy
Goiter.diagnosis: physical examination, blood tests (to measure levels of thyroid hormones and TSH), ultrasound, thyroid scan, fine-needle aspiration biopsy

Gestational Diabetes.symptoms: often asymptomatic, excessive thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, nausea, blurred vision, recurrent infections (such as urinary tract infections or yeast infections), sugar in urine detected during routine screening
Gestational Diabetes.precautions: regular prenatal care and screenings, maintain a healthy diet (focus on whole grains, lean proteins, fruits, and vegetables), engage in regular physical activity, manage weight gain according to medical guidelines, monitor blood sugar levels as recommended by healthcare provider
Gestational Diabetes.drugs: insulin therapy (if diet and exercise are not enough to control blood sugar levels), oral hypoglycemic agents (such as metformin, although not all are recommended during pregnancy)
Gestational Diabetes.diagnosis: oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), fasting blood glucose test, regular blood glucose monitoring during pregnancy

Heart Attack.symptoms: chest pain or discomfort, pain in the arm, shoulder, neck, back, or jaw, shortness of breath, nausea or vomiting, lightheadedness or dizziness, cold sweats, fatigue, heartburn or indigestion, anxiety
Heart Attack.precautions: maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, avoid smoking, manage stress, control blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes, limit alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy weight
Heart Attack.drugs: aspirin, thrombolytics (to dissolve blood clots), antiplatelet agents (such as clopidogrel), beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, statins, pain relievers (such as morphine), anticoagulants (such as heparin)
Heart Attack.diagnosis: electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests (to detect cardiac enzymes), chest X-ray, echocardiogram, coronary angiography, stress tests

Hypothyroidism.symptoms: fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin and hair, constipation, muscle weakness, depression, memory problems, slow heart rate, hoarseness, elevated blood cholesterol, joint pain
Hypothyroidism.precautions: regular thyroid function tests, maintain a balanced diet with adequate iodine, avoid goitrogens (in excess, found in certain raw vegetables), manage stress, avoid smoking
Hypothyroidism.drugs: levothyroxine (synthetic thyroid hormone), adjust dose based on regular TSH testing
Hypothyroidism.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure TSH, T3, and T4 levels), thyroid antibody tests, ultrasound of the thyroid (in some cases)

Herpes Zoster.symptoms: painful rash (typically on one side of the body or face), fluid-filled blisters, itching, fever, headache, chills, upset stomach, fatigue, sensitivity to light
Herpes Zoster.precautions: get vaccinated (shingles vaccine), avoid contact with individuals with chickenpox or shingles, maintain a healthy immune system, practice good hygiene
Herpes Zoster.drugs: antiviral medications (such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or NSAIDs), corticosteroids (for severe cases), topical creams (such as lidocaine), anticonvulsants or antidepressants (for nerve pain)
Herpes Zoster.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test, direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test, viral culture

Hepatitis C.symptoms: often asymptomatic, fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, joint pain, clay-colored stools, itchy skin, fever
Hepatitis C.precautions: avoid sharing needles or personal items (such as razors or toothbrushes), practice safe sex, get tested regularly if at high risk, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, get vaccinated for hepatitis A and B
Hepatitis C.drugs: direct-acting antivirals (DAAs), interferon (less commonly used now), ribavirin (in combination with other medications), liver transplantation (for severe cases)
Hepatitis C.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect HCV antibodies and RNA), liver function tests, liver biopsy (to assess liver damage), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI)

Hemophilia.symptoms: prolonged bleeding, spontaneous bleeding (into joints, muscles, or other tissues), excessive bleeding from cuts or injuries, frequent nosebleeds, blood in urine or stool, large or deep bruises, joint pain and swelling
Hemophilia.precautions: avoid activities with a high risk of injury, use protective gear during physical activities, maintain good dental hygiene, inform healthcare providers of condition before procedures, avoid certain medications (such as aspirin or NSAIDs)
Hemophilia.drugs: clotting factor replacement therapy (factor VIII or IX concentrates), desmopressin (for mild hemophilia A), antifibrinolytic medications (such as tranexamic acid), gene therapy (emerging treatment)
Hemophilia.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure clotting factor levels), genetic testing (to identify mutations in the factor VIII or IX gene), family history assessment

Hepatitis A.symptoms: fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, fever, dark urine, jaundice, joint pain, clay-colored stools, itchy skin
Hepatitis A.precautions: get vaccinated, practice good hand hygiene, avoid consuming contaminated food or water, avoid raw or undercooked shellfish, practice safe travel hygiene in endemic areas
Hepatitis A.drugs: supportive care (rest, hydration, and nutrition), medications for nausea or pain relief (such as antiemetics or acetaminophen), avoid alcohol and hepatotoxic substances
Hepatitis A.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect HAV antibodies), liver function tests, clinical evaluation based on symptoms and exposure history

Head and Neck Cancer.symptoms: lump or sore that doesn't heal, persistent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, change in voice, unexplained weight loss, ear pain, hoarseness, bleeding from the nose or mouth, chronic sinus infections, white or red patches in the mouth
Head and Neck Cancer.precautions: avoid tobacco and alcohol, maintain good oral hygiene, protect against HPV (vaccination), avoid exposure to harmful chemicals, regular dental check-ups, maintain a healthy diet
Head and Neck Cancer.drugs: chemotherapy (such as cisplatin, carboplatin), targeted therapy (such as cetuximab), immunotherapy (such as pembrolizumab), pain relievers, radiation therapy
Head and Neck Cancer.diagnosis: physical exam, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI, PET scan), biopsy, endoscopy, blood tests

High Cholesterol.symptoms: often asymptomatic, chest pain (angina), heart attack, stroke, pain while walking (due to artery blockages), yellowish deposits of cholesterol (xanthomas)
High Cholesterol.precautions: maintain a healthy diet (low in saturated and trans fats), regular physical activity, avoid smoking, maintain a healthy weight, limit alcohol intake, manage stress
High Cholesterol.drugs: statins (such as atorvastatin, simvastatin), bile-acid-binding resins, cholesterol absorption inhibitors (such as ezetimibe), PCSK9 inhibitors (such as alirocumab), fibrates, niacin
High Cholesterol.diagnosis: blood tests (lipid panel to measure total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, triglycerides)

Hypercalcemia.symptoms: nausea and vomiting, frequent urination, increased thirst, constipation, abdominal pain, muscle weakness, confusion, fatigue, kidney stones, bone pain, irregular heart rhythms
Hypercalcemia.precautions: regular monitoring of calcium levels (especially if at risk), adequate hydration, avoid excessive calcium and vitamin D intake, manage underlying conditions (such as hyperparathyroidism), avoid certain medications (such as thiazide diuretics)
Hypercalcemia.drugs: bisphosphonates (such as alendronate), calcitonin, corticosteroids, IV fluids, loop diuretics (such as furosemide), denosumab, dialysis (in severe cases)
Hypercalcemia.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure calcium and parathyroid hormone levels), urine tests (to measure calcium excretion), imaging tests (such as bone densitometry, X-rays), ECG

Hashimoto's Disease.symptoms: fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin and hair, constipation, muscle weakness, depression, memory problems, slow heart rate, hoarseness, elevated blood cholesterol, joint pain
Hashimoto's Disease.precautions: regular thyroid function tests, maintain a balanced diet with adequate iodine, avoid excessive consumption of goitrogens, manage stress, avoid smoking
Hashimoto's Disease.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure TSH, T3, T4, and thyroid antibodies), ultrasound of the thyroid

Hepatitis B.symptoms: fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, joint pain, jaundice, clay-colored stools
Hepatitis B.precautions: get vaccinated, avoid sharing needles or personal items, practice safe sex, avoid exposure to infected blood or bodily fluids, get regular screenings if at high risk
Hepatitis B.drugs: antiviral medications (such as entecavir, tenofovir), interferon injections, liver transplant (in severe cases)
Hepatitis B.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect HBV antigens and antibodies), liver function tests, liver biopsy, imaging tests (such as ultrasound)

Hand Foot Mouth Disease.symptoms: fever, sore throat, painful red spots or blisters on hands, feet, and inside the mouth, loss of appetite, irritability (in infants and toddlers), headache, fatigue
Hand Foot Mouth Disease.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals, disinfect contaminated surfaces, avoid sharing utensils or personal items
Hand Foot Mouth Disease.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), topical oral anesthetics, hydration therapy
Hand Foot Mouth Disease.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, throat swab or stool sample (to identify the virus)

Hyperthyroidism.symptoms: weight loss, rapid heartbeat, increased appetite, nervousness or anxiety, tremors, sweating, heat intolerance, changes in menstrual patterns, frequent bowel movements, fatigue, muscle weakness, goiter (enlarged thyroid gland)
Hyperthyroidism.precautions: regular thyroid function tests, avoid excessive iodine intake, manage stress, maintain a balanced diet
Hyperthyroidism.drugs: antithyroid medications (such as methimazole, propylthiouracil), beta blockers, radioactive iodine therapy, surgery (thyroidectomy)
Hyperthyroidism.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure TSH, T3, and T4 levels), radioactive iodine uptake test, thyroid scan

Hemochromatosis.symptoms: fatigue, joint pain, abdominal pain, liver dysfunction, diabetes, heart abnormalities, skin darkening (bronzing), loss of libido, testicular atrophy
Hemochromatosis.precautions: regular monitoring of iron levels, avoid iron supplements and vitamin C supplements, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, regular phlebotomy (blood removal)
Hemochromatosis.drugs: phlebotomy (to remove excess iron), chelation therapy (such as deferoxamine, deferasirox), treatment of complications (such as liver disease, diabetes)
Hemochromatosis.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure serum ferritin and transferrin saturation), genetic testing, liver biopsy, MRI (to measure iron levels in the liver)

Hay Fever.symptoms: sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, itchy eyes, nose, or throat, watery eyes, cough, fatigue, sinus pressure, postnasal drip
Hay Fever.precautions: avoid exposure to allergens (such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander), use air purifiers, keep windows closed during high pollen seasons, wash hands and face after being outside, use hypoallergenic bedding
Hay Fever.drugs: antihistamines (such as loratadine, cetirizine), nasal corticosteroids (such as fluticasone, mometasone), decongestants (such as pseudoephedrine), leukotriene receptor antagonists (such as montelukast), allergy shots (immunotherapy)
Hay Fever.diagnosis: physical examination, allergy testing (skin prick test or blood test), nasal endoscopy (in some cases)

Hepatitis E.symptoms: fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, dark urine, clay-colored stools, joint pain
Hepatitis E.precautions: maintain good sanitation and hygiene, avoid drinking untreated water, avoid raw or undercooked meat (especially pork, wild game), practice safe food handling
Hepatitis E.drugs: supportive care (rest, hydration, and nutrition), ribavirin (in some chronic cases), avoid alcohol and hepatotoxic substances
Hepatitis E.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect HEV antibodies and RNA), liver function tests, clinical evaluation based on symptoms and exposure history

Hydronephrosis.symptoms: flank pain, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, urinary problems (such as urgency, frequency, or incontinence), blood in urine, recurrent urinary tract infections, fever (if infection is present)
Hydronephrosis.precautions: manage underlying conditions (such as kidney stones or BPH), maintain adequate hydration, avoid holding urine for long periods, regular follow-ups if at risk
Hydronephrosis.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or NSAIDs), antibiotics (if infection is present), treatment of underlying cause (such as medications to dissolve kidney stones or relieve prostate enlargement)
Hydronephrosis.diagnosis: ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, intravenous pyelogram (IVP), urinalysis, blood tests (to assess kidney function)

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).symptoms: abdominal pain or cramping, bloating, gas, diarrhea, constipation, alternating diarrhea and constipation, mucus in stool, changes in bowel habits, indigestion
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).precautions: maintain a high-fiber diet, avoid trigger foods (such as dairy, gluten, caffeine), eat smaller, more frequent meals, manage stress, drink plenty of water, regular exercise
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).drugs: fiber supplements (such as psyllium), antispasmodics (such as hyoscine, dicyclomine), laxatives (for constipation), antidiarrheal medications (such as loperamide), antidepressants (for pain relief), probiotics
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).diagnosis: medical history and symptom review, physical examination, blood tests, stool tests, colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy, breath tests for lactose intolerance or bacterial overgrowth

Impetigo.symptoms: red sores that quickly rupture, ooze for a few days, then form a yellowish-brown crust, itching, soreness, swollen lymph nodes, blisters (in bullous impetigo), reddened skin (especially around the nose and mouth)
Impetigo.precautions: maintain good hygiene, avoid sharing personal items, keep nails short and clean, avoid scratching sores, wash affected areas with soap and water, cover sores with gauze or bandages
Impetigo.drugs: topical antibiotics (such as mupirocin, retapamulin), oral antibiotics (such as cephalexin, dicloxacillin, or clindamycin in severe cases)
Impetigo.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, bacterial culture or swab test (if necessary)

Iron Deficiency Anemia.symptoms: fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness or lightheadedness, cold hands and feet, brittle nails, headache, irregular heartbeat, chest pain, cravings for non-nutritive substances (pica)
Iron Deficiency Anemia.precautions: maintain a diet rich in iron (such as lean meats, beans, leafy green vegetables, fortified cereals), enhance iron absorption with vitamin C-rich foods, avoid excessive intake of tea or coffee with meals, manage underlying causes (such as menstrual bleeding or gastrointestinal conditions)
Iron Deficiency Anemia.drugs: oral iron supplements (such as ferrous sulfate), intravenous iron therapy (in severe cases), treatment of underlying cause (such as medications for gastrointestinal bleeding)
Iron Deficiency Anemia.diagnosis: complete blood count (CBC), serum ferritin test, serum iron test, total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) test, reticulocyte count

Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).symptoms: diarrhea, abdominal pain and cramping, blood in stool, reduced appetite, weight loss, fatigue, fever, joint pain, eye inflammation, skin disorders
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).precautions: maintain a balanced, low-residue diet, avoid trigger foods (such as high-fat, high-fiber foods), manage stress, quit smoking, regular exercise, stay hydrated
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).drugs: aminosalicylates (such as mesalamine), corticosteroids, immunomodulators (such as azathioprine), biologic therapies (such as infliximab, adalimumab), antibiotics (for complications), antidiarrheal medications
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).diagnosis: colonoscopy, endoscopy, blood tests (to detect inflammation markers), stool tests, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI), biopsy

Influenza.symptoms: fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle aches, headache, fatigue, chills, nausea, vomiting (more common in children)
Influenza.precautions: get vaccinated annually, practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with sick individuals, cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, stay home when feeling ill
Influenza.drugs: antiviral medications (such as oseltamivir, zanamivir), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), decongestants, cough suppressants, hydration therapy
Influenza.diagnosis: physical examination, rapid influenza diagnostic tests (RIDTs), RT-PCR testing, viral culture (less common)

Insomnia.symptoms: difficulty falling asleep, waking up during the night, waking up too early, not feeling well-rested, daytime fatigue, irritability or mood disturbances, difficulty concentrating, headaches, gastrointestinal symptoms, anxiety about sleep
Insomnia.precautions: maintain a regular sleep schedule, create a comfortable sleep environment, avoid caffeine and heavy meals before bedtime, limit naps, practice relaxation techniques, avoid electronic devices before bed
Insomnia.drugs: over-the-counter sleep aids (such as diphenhydramine), prescription medications (such as zolpidem, eszopiclone), melatonin supplements, cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I)
Insomnia.diagnosis: sleep history and diary, physical examination, sleep studies (such as polysomnography), actigraphy, questionnaires (such as the Insomnia Severity Index)

Jaundice.symptoms: yellowing of the skin and eyes, dark urine, pale stools, itching, fatigue, abdominal pain, weight loss, vomiting, fever, headache
Jaundice.precautions: maintain liver health, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, get vaccinated for hepatitis, practice good hygiene, avoid exposure to toxins, maintain a balanced diet
Jaundice.drugs: depends on the cause; may include antiviral medications for hepatitis, corticosteroids for inflammation, medications to relieve itching (such as cholestyramine), supportive care
Jaundice.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure bilirubin levels and liver function), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), liver biopsy, physical examination

Kidney Stones.symptoms: severe pain in the side and back, pain that radiates to the lower abdomen and groin, pain during urination, pink, red, or brown urine, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, nausea and vomiting, frequent urination, fever and chills (if infection is present)
Kidney Stones.precautions: stay hydrated, reduce salt and protein intake, avoid high-oxalate foods, maintain a balanced diet, avoid excessive consumption of calcium supplements, regular physical activity
Kidney Stones.drugs: pain relievers (such as ibuprofen, acetaminophen), alpha blockers (such as tamsulosin), medications to prevent stone formation (such as thiazide diuretics, allopurinol), lithotripsy, surgical removal
Kidney Stones.diagnosis: urinalysis, blood tests, imaging tests (such as CT scan, X-ray, ultrasound), stone analysis

Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis).symptoms: fever, chills, back or side pain, abdominal pain, frequent urination, burning sensation during urination, nausea and vomiting, blood in urine, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, fatigue
Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis).precautions: drink plenty of fluids, urinate frequently, maintain good hygiene, avoid using irritants in the genital area, practice safe sex, manage underlying conditions (such as urinary tract infections promptly)
Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis).drugs: antibiotics (such as ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin), pain relievers, hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics (in severe cases), supportive care
Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis).diagnosis: urinalysis, urine culture, blood tests, imaging tests (such as CT scan, ultrasound), physical examination

Kidney Cysts.symptoms: often asymptomatic, pain or discomfort in the back or side, fever (if cyst becomes infected), blood in urine, frequent urination, high blood pressure, swelling in the abdomen, feeling of fullness
Kidney Cysts.precautions: regular monitoring if at risk, maintain adequate hydration, avoid smoking, manage blood pressure, healthy diet, regular check-ups
Kidney Cysts.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen), antibiotics (if cyst is infected), surgical drainage, laparoscopic surgery (in severe cases), supportive care
Kidney Cysts.diagnosis: ultrasound, CT scan, MRI, urinalysis, blood tests

Klinefelter Syndrome.symptoms: low testosterone, reduced muscle mass, reduced facial and body hair, enlarged breast tissue (gynecomastia), small testes, infertility, learning difficulties, delayed speech and language development, tall stature, fatigue
Klinefelter Syndrome.precautions: regular medical check-ups, testosterone replacement therapy, early intervention for developmental delays, support for learning difficulties, psychological support
Klinefelter Syndrome.drugs: testosterone replacement therapy, fertility treatment (such as assisted reproductive technologies), speech and physical therapy, educational support
Klinefelter Syndrome.diagnosis: karyotype analysis (to detect extra X chromosome), hormone testing, semen analysis, physical examination

Kawasaki Disease.symptoms: fever lasting more than five days, rash, red eyes (conjunctivitis), red, cracked lips and swollen tongue (strawberry tongue), swollen hands and feet, peeling skin on fingers and toes, swollen lymph nodes, irritability, joint pain
Kawasaki Disease.precautions: early diagnosis and treatment, regular medical check-ups, monitor for heart complications, avoid exposure to infections, supportive care
Kawasaki Disease.drugs: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), aspirin, corticosteroids (in some cases), immunosuppressants (such as infliximab in resistant cases)
Kawasaki Disease.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests, echocardiogram, electrocardiogram (ECG), urine tests

Leprosy.symptoms: light-colored or red skin patches with reduced sensation, numbness and weakness in hands and feet, muscle weakness, enlarged nerves, ulcers on the soles of feet, eye problems leading to blindness, loss of eyebrows or eyelashes
Leprosy.precautions: early diagnosis and treatment, avoid close contact with untreated infected individuals, regular medical check-ups, maintain good hygiene
Leprosy.drugs: multidrug therapy (MDT) including dapsone, rifampicin, and clofazimine, supportive care for nerve damage
Leprosy.diagnosis: skin biopsy, skin smear test, clinical evaluation, nerve biopsy

Lupus.symptoms: fatigue, joint pain and swelling, skin rashes (including butterfly-shaped rash on the face), fever, photosensitivity, chest pain, headaches, hair loss, Raynaud's phenomenon (fingers turning white or blue in cold), mouth ulcers
Lupus.precautions: avoid excessive sun exposure, regular medical follow-ups, maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, avoid smoking, stress management
Lupus.drugs: NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen), antimalarial drugs (such as hydroxychloroquine), corticosteroids, immunosuppressants (such as azathioprine), biologic agents (such as belimumab)
Lupus.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (ANA, anti-dsDNA), urinalysis, imaging tests (such as X-rays, echocardiogram), biopsy (of affected organs)

Leukemia.symptoms: fatigue, frequent infections, fever or chills, easy bruising or bleeding, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes, bone pain, night sweats, petechiae (small red spots on the skin), frequent nosebleeds
Leukemia.precautions: regular health screenings, avoid exposure to high levels of radiation and toxic chemicals, maintain a healthy lifestyle, avoid smoking, genetic counseling if at risk
Leukemia.drugs: chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy (such as imatinib), immunotherapy, stem cell transplant, corticosteroids
Leukemia.diagnosis: blood tests (complete blood count, blood smear), bone marrow biopsy, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI), lumbar puncture

Lichen Sclerosus.symptoms: white, patchy skin that appears thinner than normal, itching, discomfort or pain, blisters, tearing or bleeding of the skin, painful intercourse, scarring and narrowing of the genital area
Lichen Sclerosus.precautions: avoid irritants (such as perfumed soaps), maintain good hygiene, avoid tight clothing, use lubrication during intercourse, regular medical check-ups
Lichen Sclerosus.drugs: topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors (such as tacrolimus), moisturizers, retinoids (in severe cases)
Lichen Sclerosus.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, skin biopsy, medical history

Liver Disease.symptoms: jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain and swelling, swelling in the legs and ankles, itchy skin, dark urine, pale stool, nausea or vomiting, loss of appetite, easy bruising
Liver Disease.precautions: limit alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy weight, avoid risky behaviors (such as sharing needles), get vaccinated for hepatitis, avoid exposure to toxins, regular medical check-ups
Liver Disease.drugs: depends on the cause; may include antiviral medications for hepatitis, corticosteroids, medications to manage symptoms (such as diuretics for swelling), lifestyle changes
Liver Disease.diagnosis: blood tests (liver function tests), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), liver biopsy, clinical evaluation

Liver Cancer.symptoms: unintended weight loss, loss of appetite, upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, general weakness and fatigue, enlarged liver, jaundice, white, chalky stools
Liver Cancer.precautions: avoid hepatitis infection (get vaccinated), limit alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy weight, regular screening for high-risk individuals, avoid exposure to aflatoxins, avoid smoking
Liver Cancer.drugs: surgery (such as partial hepatectomy), liver transplant, ablation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy (such as sorafenib), immunotherapy (such as nivolumab)
Liver Cancer.diagnosis: imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), blood tests (such as AFP levels), biopsy, clinical evaluation

Labyrinthitis.symptoms: vertigo, dizziness, loss of balance, hearing loss, tinnitus, ear pain, nausea and vomiting, difficulty focusing eyes, headache, fever (if infection is present)
Labyrinthitis.precautions: avoid sudden movements, manage underlying infections promptly, avoid alcohol, maintain good ear hygiene, avoid stress
Labyrinthitis.drugs: antibiotics (if bacterial infection), antiviral medications (if viral infection), corticosteroids, antihistamines (such as meclizine), anti-nausea medications (such as promethazine), vestibular rehabilitation exercises
Labyrinthitis.diagnosis: hearing tests, balance tests, imaging tests (such as MRI), clinical evaluation, blood tests (to check for infection)

Lyme Disease.symptoms: bull's-eye rash (erythema migrans), fever, chills, fatigue, body aches, headache, neck stiffness, swollen lymph nodes, joint pain, neurological problems (in later stages), heart palpitations
Lyme Disease.precautions: avoid tick-infested areas, use insect repellent, wear long sleeves and pants in wooded areas, check for ticks after being outdoors, promptly remove ticks with tweezers
Lyme Disease.drugs: antibiotics (such as doxycycline, amoxicillin, cefuroxime), pain relievers (such as ibuprofen), supportive care for symptoms
Lyme Disease.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (ELISA, Western blot), physical examination, sometimes a lumbar puncture or ECG if neurological or cardiac symptoms are present
