Leishmaniasis.symptoms: skin sores (cutaneous leishmaniasis), fever, weight loss, enlargement of the spleen and liver (visceral leishmaniasis), swollen glands, anemia, low white blood cell count, low platelet count
Leishmaniasis.precautions: avoid sandfly bites (use insect repellent, bed nets), wear protective clothing, avoid outdoor activities from dusk to dawn, ensure good sanitation, control sandfly population
Leishmaniasis.drugs: antiparasitic medications (such as miltefosine, amphotericin B, pentavalent antimonials), supportive care, wound care for skin lesions
Leishmaniasis.diagnosis: skin biopsy, blood tests, bone marrow biopsy, clinical evaluation, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests

Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA) Disease.symptoms: chest pain or discomfort (angina), shortness of breath, fatigue, lightheadedness or dizziness, heart palpitations, sweating, nausea
Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA) Disease.precautions: maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, avoid smoking, manage blood pressure and cholesterol levels, regular medical check-ups, manage stress
Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA) Disease.drugs: antiplatelet agents (such as aspirin, clopidogrel), statins, beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, nitrates, revascularization procedures (such as angioplasty, stenting, or coronary artery bypass grafting)
Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA) Disease.diagnosis: electrocardiogram (ECG), stress test, echocardiogram, coronary angiography, CT coronary angiogram, blood tests

Lewy Body Dementia.symptoms: visual hallucinations, movement disorders (such as Parkinsonism), cognitive decline, fluctuations in attention and alertness, sleep disturbances (such as REM sleep behavior disorder), depression, memory problems, autonomic dysfunction
Lewy Body Dementia.precautions: regular medical check-ups, maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, manage cardiovascular health, cognitive stimulation, create a safe home environment
Lewy Body Dementia.drugs: cholinesterase inhibitors (such as rivastigmine), medications for Parkinsonian symptoms (such as levodopa), antipsychotics (with caution, such as quetiapine), medications for sleep disturbances, antidepressants
Lewy Body Dementia.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, neurological examination, cognitive tests, brain imaging (such as MRI, CT scan, DaTscan), sleep studies, blood tests

Lactose Intolerance.symptoms: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, bloating, gas, stomach rumbling, fatigue (in severe cases), headache
Lactose Intolerance.precautions: limit or avoid lactose-containing foods, use lactose-free products, take lactase enzyme supplements, maintain adequate calcium and vitamin D intake, read food labels carefully
Lactose Intolerance.drugs: lactase enzyme supplements, probiotics, calcium and vitamin D supplements, antidiarrheal medications (if necessary)
Lactose Intolerance.diagnosis: lactose tolerance test, hydrogen breath test, stool acidity test, clinical evaluation, elimination diet

Meningitis.symptoms: severe headache, high fever, stiff neck, nausea or vomiting, sensitivity to light, confusion or altered mental status, seizures, sleepiness or difficulty waking, loss of appetite, skin rash (in some cases)
Meningitis.precautions: get vaccinated (such as meningococcal, pneumococcal vaccines), practice good hygiene, avoid sharing personal items, manage underlying conditions, avoid close contact with infected individuals
Meningitis.drugs: antibiotics (for bacterial meningitis, such as ceftriaxone), antiviral medications (for viral meningitis, such as acyclovir), corticosteroids (to reduce inflammation), supportive care (such as fluids and pain relievers)
Meningitis.diagnosis: lumbar puncture (spinal tap), blood cultures, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI), physical examination, clinical evaluation

Measles.symptoms: high fever, cough, runny nose, red, watery eyes (conjunctivitis), Koplik spots (small white spots inside the mouth), red, blotchy skin rash that usually starts on the face and spreads, fatigue, sore throat, body aches
Measles.precautions: get vaccinated (MMR vaccine), practice good hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals, isolate infected individuals, manage symptoms promptly
Measles.drugs: supportive care (such as fluids, rest, and pain relievers like acetaminophen), vitamin A supplements (to reduce the severity), antiviral medications (in some cases, such as ribavirin)
Measles.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (to detect measles virus antibodies), throat swab or nasal swab, urine test

Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).symptoms: chest pain or discomfort (often described as pressure, squeezing, or fullness), pain or discomfort in one or both arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach, shortness of breath, nausea or vomiting, lightheadedness or dizziness, cold sweat, fatigue
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).precautions: maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, avoid smoking, manage blood pressure and cholesterol levels, regular medical check-ups, manage stress
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).drugs: antiplatelet agents (such as aspirin, clopidogrel), anticoagulants (such as heparin), thrombolytics (clot busters), beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, statins
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).diagnosis: electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests (such as troponin levels), coronary angiography, echocardiogram, stress tests, chest X-ray

Multiple Sclerosis.symptoms: fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or tingling, muscle weakness or spasms, vision problems (such as blurred vision, double vision), dizziness, bladder and bowel dysfunction, cognitive impairment, pain, depression
Multiple Sclerosis.precautions: maintain a healthy lifestyle, avoid smoking, manage stress, regular exercise, vitamin D supplementation, avoid extreme heat
Multiple Sclerosis.drugs: disease-modifying therapies (such as interferon beta, glatiramer acetate, natalizumab), corticosteroids (for acute relapses), muscle relaxants, medications for fatigue and pain management, physical therapy
Multiple Sclerosis.diagnosis: MRI, lumbar puncture (spinal tap), evoked potentials test, blood tests, clinical evaluation

Myocarditis.symptoms: chest pain, rapid or abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias), shortness of breath, fatigue, fluid retention with swelling of the legs, ankles, and feet, fever, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, fainting
Myocarditis.precautions: avoid exposure to infections, maintain good hygiene, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, regular medical check-ups, manage underlying conditions, avoid strenuous activities during recovery
Myocarditis.drugs: anti-inflammatory medications (such as ibuprofen), corticosteroids, antiviral medications (if caused by a virus), heart medications (such as beta blockers, ACE inhibitors), diuretics
Myocarditis.diagnosis: electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests, chest X-ray, echocardiogram, MRI, endomyocardial biopsy

Malaria.symptoms: fever, chills, headache, nausea and vomiting, muscle pain and fatigue, sweating, abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, jaundice
Malaria.precautions: use insect repellent, sleep under insecticide-treated bed nets, take antimalarial medications (when traveling to endemic areas), avoid mosquito bites (by wearing protective clothing), regular medical check-ups
Malaria.drugs: antimalarial medications (such as chloroquine, artemisinin-based combination therapies), supportive care (such as fluids, pain relievers), blood transfusion (in severe cases)
Malaria.diagnosis: blood smear microscopy, rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs), PCR testing, clinical evaluation

Meniere's Disease.symptoms: recurring episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus (ringing in the ear), feeling of fullness in the ear, nausea, vomiting, balance problems, sweating
Meniere's Disease.precautions: avoid high-salt diet, limit caffeine and alcohol intake, manage stress, regular medical check-ups, avoid exposure to loud noises
Meniere's Disease.drugs: diuretics (to reduce fluid retention), anti-nausea medications (such as promethazine), antihistamines (such as meclizine), corticosteroids (for severe cases), betahistine
Meniere's Disease.diagnosis: hearing tests (audiometry), balance tests (electronystagmography, rotary-chair testing), MRI, clinical evaluation

Multiple Myeloma.symptoms: bone pain (especially in the back or ribs), fatigue, frequent infections, weight loss, excessive thirst, nausea, constipation, weakness or numbness in the legs, frequent urination
Multiple Myeloma.precautions: regular medical check-ups, avoid smoking, maintain a healthy diet, manage stress, avoid exposure to infections, stay hydrated
Multiple Myeloma.drugs: chemotherapy, corticosteroids, immunomodulatory drugs (such as thalidomide, lenalidomide), proteasome inhibitors (such as bortezomib), stem cell transplant, supportive care (such as pain management)
Multiple Myeloma.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect abnormal antibodies), urine tests, bone marrow biopsy, imaging tests (such as X-rays, MRI, CT scan), clinical evaluation

Muscular Dystrophy.symptoms: progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, frequent falls, trouble running or jumping, large calf muscles, learning disabilities, difficulty breathing or swallowing, muscle pain and stiffness, scoliosis
Muscular Dystrophy.precautions: regular physical therapy, avoid excessive physical strain, maintain a healthy diet, respiratory care, cardiac monitoring, supportive care
Muscular Dystrophy.drugs: corticosteroids (such as prednisone), heart medications (such as ACE inhibitors, beta blockers), physical therapy, assistive devices (such as braces, wheelchairs), surgical interventions (for scoliosis or contractures)
Muscular Dystrophy.diagnosis: genetic testing, muscle biopsy, blood tests (for elevated creatine kinase), electromyography (EMG), clinical evaluation

Metabolic Syndrome.symptoms: increased waist circumference, high blood pressure, elevated fasting blood sugar, high triglyceride levels, low HDL cholesterol, fatigue, difficulty losing weight, increased thirst and urination, shortness of breath
Metabolic Syndrome.precautions: maintain a healthy diet, regular exercise, avoid smoking, manage stress, regular medical check-ups, maintain a healthy weight
Metabolic Syndrome.drugs: antihypertensive medications, cholesterol-lowering drugs (such as statins), medications to manage blood sugar (such as metformin), weight loss medications, aspirin (to reduce risk of cardiovascular events)
Metabolic Syndrome.diagnosis: blood tests (lipid profile, fasting glucose), blood pressure measurement, waist circumference measurement, clinical evaluation

Monkeypox Disease.symptoms: fever, headache, muscle aches, backache, swollen lymph nodes, chills, exhaustion, rash (which can look like pimples or blisters) that appears on the face, inside the mouth, and on other parts of the body
Monkeypox Disease.precautions: avoid contact with infected animals, practice good hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals, isolate infected individuals, use personal protective equipment (PPE)
Monkeypox Disease.drugs: supportive care (such as fluids, pain relievers), antiviral medications (such as tecovirimat), vaccine (for prevention, such as smallpox vaccine)
Monkeypox Disease.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, PCR testing of lesion samples, blood tests, biopsy (if necessary)

Myasthenia Gravis.symptoms: muscle weakness (especially in the face, neck, and limbs), drooping eyelids (ptosis), double vision (diplopia), difficulty speaking, chewing, or swallowing, fatigue, difficulty breathing, unstable gait
Myasthenia Gravis.precautions: avoid stress and fatigue, conserve energy, maintain a well-balanced diet, avoid excessive heat, practice good respiratory hygiene, avoid exposure to infections
Myasthenia Gravis.drugs: acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (such as pyridostigmine), immunosuppressants (such as prednisone, azathioprine), intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), plasma exchange (plasmapheresis)
Myasthenia Gravis.diagnosis: nerve conduction studies, electromyography (EMG), blood tests for acetylcholine receptor antibodies, tensilon test, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI)

Mumps.symptoms: swollen and tender salivary glands (usually the parotid glands), fever, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, loss of appetite, pain while chewing or swallowing, earache, testicular pain (in males)
Mumps.precautions: get vaccinated (MMR vaccine), practice good hygiene (such as handwashing), avoid sharing utensils or drinks with infected individuals, cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing
Mumps.drugs: mainly supportive care for symptoms, such as pain relievers (acetaminophen or ibuprofen) for fever and discomfort
Mumps.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, viral culture or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test of saliva or throat swab, blood tests for mumps antibodies

Myositis.symptoms: muscle weakness, muscle pain or tenderness, difficulty rising from a seated position, fatigue, joint pain, difficulty swallowing (in inclusion body myositis), skin rash (in dermatomyositis)
Myositis.precautions: avoid overexertion and fatigue, maintain a balanced diet, physical therapy to maintain muscle strength and flexibility, protect skin from sun exposure (in dermatomyositis)
Myositis.drugs: corticosteroids (such as prednisone), immunosuppressants (such as methotrexate, azathioprine), intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), biologic therapies (such as rituximab)
Myositis.diagnosis: blood tests (to check for muscle enzyme levels and autoantibodies), electromyography (EMG), muscle biopsy, imaging tests (such as MRI)

Nasal Cancer.symptoms: nasal congestion and obstruction, nosebleeds, nasal discharge (which may be bloody), facial pain or pressure, headaches, swelling around the eyes, decreased sense of smell, numbness or pain in the face
Nasal Cancer.precautions: avoid exposure to known carcinogens (such as tobacco smoke, industrial chemicals), protect against workplace exposures (such as wearing protective equipment), maintain good nasal hygiene
Nasal Cancer.drugs: depends on the type and stage of cancer; may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy
Nasal Cancer.diagnosis: nasal endoscopy, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI), biopsy, blood tests (tumor markers in some cases)

Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD).symptoms: often asymptomatic, fatigue, abdominal discomfort, enlarged liver, elevated liver enzymes (detected on blood tests), weakness, jaundice (in severe cases), swelling in the legs (edema), confusion (in severe cases of liver failure)
Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD).precautions: maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet low in saturated fats and sugars, exercise regularly, avoid excessive alcohol consumption, manage underlying conditions (such as diabetes and high cholesterol)
Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD).drugs: lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise), medications to manage underlying conditions (such as diabetes and high cholesterol), antioxidants (such as vitamin E), liver health supplements
Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD).diagnosis: blood tests (liver function tests), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), liver biopsy (in some cases), clinical evaluation

Nipah Virus.symptoms: fever, headache, dizziness, drowsiness, mental confusion, disorientation, neurological signs (such as seizures, coma), respiratory distress, cough, vomiting, sore throat
Nipah Virus.precautions: avoid exposure to sick animals (especially pigs and bats), avoid drinking raw date palm sap (a known source of infection), practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals
Nipah Virus.drugs: mainly supportive care for symptoms, such as fever reducers, pain relievers, and hydration therapy; there is no specific antiviral treatment available for Nipah virus infection
Nipah Virus.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect antibodies), polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test of blood or throat swab, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI)

Osteoarthritis.symptoms: joint pain (particularly after activity or towards the end of the day), stiffness (especially in the morning or after periods of inactivity), swelling, tenderness, loss of flexibility, grating sensation during joint movement
Osteoarthritis.precautions: maintain a healthy weight, exercise regularly (with low-impact activities), protect your joints from injury, use assistive devices if needed, avoid repetitive stress on joints, manage pain and inflammation
Osteoarthritis.drugs: acetaminophen, NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen, naproxen), topical pain relievers (such as creams or patches), corticosteroid injections, hyaluronic acid injections
Osteoarthritis.diagnosis: medical history and physical examination, X-rays, MRI or CT scans, joint fluid analysis (if necessary)

Osteopenia.symptoms: usually asymptomatic until a fracture occurs, bone pain, loss of height over time, stooped posture, increased susceptibility to fractures
Osteopenia.precautions: get adequate calcium and vitamin D through diet and supplements, engage in weight-bearing exercises, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, prevent falls by removing hazards at home and improving balance
Osteopenia.drugs: bisphosphonates (such as alendronate, risedronate), hormone replacement therapy (in postmenopausal women), calcium and vitamin D supplements, exercise
Osteopenia.diagnosis: bone density testing (DEXA scan), medical history and physical examination, blood tests (to rule out other causes of bone loss)

Osteomyelitis.symptoms: fever, localized pain, swelling, redness, warmth over the affected area, difficulty moving the affected limb or joint, drainage of pus (if abscess forms), fatigue, irritability (in children)
Osteomyelitis.precautions: prompt treatment of infections, proper wound care, good dental hygiene, manage underlying conditions (such as diabetes), avoid injuries that can lead to open wounds
Osteomyelitis.drugs: antibiotics (usually intravenous initially, then oral), pain relievers, surgery to drain abscesses or remove infected tissue (in some cases)
Osteomyelitis.diagnosis: blood tests (elevated inflammatory markers), imaging tests (such as X-rays, MRI, CT scans), bone biopsy

Osteoporosis.symptoms: usually asymptomatic until a fracture occurs, back pain (due to compression fractures), loss of height over time, stooped posture, increased susceptibility to fractures
Osteoporosis.precautions: get adequate calcium and vitamin D through diet and supplements, engage in weight-bearing exercises, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, prevent falls by removing hazards at home and improving balance
Osteoporosis.drugs: bisphosphonates (such as alendronate, risedronate), hormone replacement therapy (in postmenopausal women), denosumab, teriparatide, calcitonin
Osteoporosis.diagnosis: bone density testing (DEXA scan), medical history and physical examination, blood tests (to rule out other causes of bone loss)

Osteomalacia.symptoms: muscle weakness, bone pain or tenderness, fractures (especially in weight-bearing bones), difficulty walking, waddling gait, bone deformities
Osteomalacia.precautions: get adequate vitamin D through diet, supplements, and sunlight exposure, consume sufficient dietary calcium, treat underlying conditions that may interfere with vitamin D metabolism
Osteomalacia.drugs: vitamin D supplements (ergocalciferol, cholecalciferol), calcium supplements, phosphate supplements (in some cases)
Osteomalacia.diagnosis: blood tests (low levels of vitamin D, calcium, and phosphorus), bone biopsy (rarely necessary)

Otitis Media.symptoms: ear pain (especially in children), difficulty hearing, fluid drainage from the ear, fever, irritability (especially in infants and young children), headache, loss of appetite, trouble sleeping
Otitis Media.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, avoid exposure to cigarette smoke, breastfeed infants if possible, keep vaccinations up to date (such as pneumococcal vaccine), avoid bottle-feeding infants in a supine position
Otitis Media.drugs: antibiotics (for bacterial infections), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), ear drops, decongestants (for congestion), antihistamines (for allergies)
Otitis Media.diagnosis: physical examination of the ear with an otoscope, pneumatic otoscopy, tympanometry, hearing tests (in older children and adults)

Osteogenesis Imperfecta.symptoms: frequent bone fractures (even with minimal trauma), blue sclerae (blue tint to the whites of the eyes), short stature, brittle teeth, hearing loss, joint laxity, bone deformities, scoliosis
Osteogenesis Imperfecta.precautions: handle affected individuals gently to avoid fractures, provide a safe environment, encourage physical activity within limits, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D intake, genetic counseling for affected individuals and families
Osteogenesis Imperfecta.drugs: bisphosphonates (such as pamidronate, alendronate) to increase bone density, pain management, physical therapy
Osteogenesis Imperfecta.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, imaging tests (X-rays, bone density testing), genetic testing

Parkinson's Disease.symptoms: tremors (often starting in hands), bradykinesia (slowed movement), rigid muscles, impaired posture and balance, loss of automatic movements, speech changes, writing changes, stooped posture, freezing of gait
Parkinson's Disease.precautions: engage in regular exercise (such as aerobic and strength training), maintain a balanced diet, get enough sleep, avoid falls (by removing hazards at home), manage constipation, stay mentally active
Parkinson's Disease.drugs: levodopa, dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors, COMT inhibitors, anticholinergics, amantadine
Parkinson's Disease.diagnosis: medical history and neurological examination, DaTscan, blood tests (to rule out other conditions)

Periodontitis.symptoms: swollen or bleeding gums, persistent bad breath, receding gums, loose teeth, pain while chewing, sensitive teeth
Periodontitis.precautions: practice good oral hygiene (brushing, flossing, rinsing with antiseptic mouthwash), regular dental check-ups and cleanings, avoid smoking, eat a balanced diet, manage underlying conditions (such as diabetes)
Periodontitis.drugs: antibiotics (for bacterial infection), scaling and root planing, periodontal surgery (for severe cases)
Periodontitis.diagnosis: dental examination, probing of the gums, X-rays

Pleural Effusion.symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain (usually sharp and worsens with deep breaths or coughing), dry cough, fever (if infection is present), difficulty breathing when lying down
Pleural Effusion.precautions: treat underlying conditions promptly (such as heart failure, pneumonia), avoid smoking, maintain a healthy weight, avoid exposure to pollutants or irritants
Pleural Effusion.drugs: depends on the cause; may include diuretics (to remove excess fluid), antibiotics (for bacterial infections), corticosteroids (for inflammation), thoracentesis (to drain fluid)
Pleural Effusion.diagnosis: physical examination, chest X-ray, ultrasound, CT scan, thoracentesis

Pericarditis.symptoms: chest pain (sharp and stabbing worsens with deep breaths or lying down), low-grade fever, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, swelling in the legs or abdomen
Pericarditis.precautions: treat underlying infections promptly, avoid smoking, manage stress, limit physical exertion, avoid over-the-counter pain relievers (such as ibuprofen) which can worsen symptoms
Pericarditis.drugs: NSAIDs (such as aspirin, ibuprofen), colchicine, corticosteroids (in severe cases), antibiotics (if bacterial infection is present)
Pericarditis.diagnosis: physical examination, chest X-ray, electrocardiogram (ECG), echocardiogram, blood tests (to rule out other causes of chest pain)

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).symptoms: lower abdominal pain, abnormal vaginal discharge (often foul-smelling), irregular menstrual bleeding, painful urination, painful intercourse, fever, nausea, vomiting
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).precautions: practice safe sex (use condoms), get regular STI screenings, avoid douching, treat STIs promptly, avoid multiple sexual partners
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).drugs: antibiotics (such as doxycycline, ceftriaxone), pain relievers, hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics (in severe cases)
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).diagnosis: pelvic examination, ultrasound, laparoscopy, endometrial biopsy, cervical cultures

Pancreatitis.symptoms: abdominal pain (often severe and radiating to the back), nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid pulse, swollen or tender abdomen, decreased appetite, unintentional weight loss, oily or greasy stools
Pancreatitis.precautions: avoid excessive alcohol consumption, maintain a healthy weight, eat a low-fat diet, avoid smoking, manage underlying conditions (such as gallstones or high triglycerides)
Pancreatitis.drugs: pain relievers, pancreatic enzyme supplements, IV fluids (for hydration and electrolyte balance), antibiotics (if infection is present)
Pancreatitis.diagnosis: blood tests (amylase, lipase), imaging tests (such as ultrasound, CT scan, MRI), endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), pancreatic biopsy

Peptic Ulcer.symptoms: burning stomach pain, bloating, belching, nausea, vomiting, dark or bloody stools, unexplained weight loss, appetite changes, heartburn
Peptic Ulcer.precautions: avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) if possible, limit alcohol consumption, quit smoking, manage stress, avoid spicy and acidic foods, eat smaller meals more frequently
Peptic Ulcer.drugs: antibiotics (if H. pylori infection is present), proton pump inhibitors (such as omeprazole, lansoprazole), H2-receptor antagonists (such as ranitidine), antacids
Peptic Ulcer.diagnosis: upper endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy), blood tests (to detect H. pylori infection), stool tests (to detect H. pylori antigens)

Polycythemia.symptoms: headache, dizziness, blurred or double vision, red skin (especially on the face), itching (especially after a hot bath or shower), fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, enlarged spleen
Polycythemia.precautions: avoid smoking, stay well-hydrated, avoid excess iron intake, manage underlying conditions (such as sleep apnea), avoid high altitudes
Polycythemia.drugs: phlebotomy (removing blood from your body), medications to reduce the production of red blood cells (such as hydroxyurea), low-dose aspirin (to reduce blood clotting), antihistamines (for itching)
Polycythemia.diagnosis: blood tests (complete blood count, erythropoietin levels), bone marrow biopsy, genetic testing (for certain forms of polycythemia vera)

Pleurisy.symptoms: sharp chest pain (worsened by breathing or coughing), shallow breathing, shortness of breath, dry cough, fever, chills, rapid heartbeat
Pleurisy.precautions: treat underlying conditions (such as infections or autoimmune diseases), avoid smoking, get vaccinated against pneumonia and influenza, practice good hygiene
Pleurisy.drugs: pain relievers (such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen), antibiotics (if bacterial infection is present), corticosteroids (for severe inflammation), antiviral medications (for viral infections)
Pleurisy.diagnosis: physical examination, chest X-ray or CT scan, blood tests, thoracentesis (removing fluid from the pleural space for analysis)

Pityriasis Rosea.symptoms: herald patch (large, pink patch of scaly skin), smaller scaly patches that spread from the herald patch, itching (mild to severe), fatigue, nausea (in rare cases), sore throat (in rare cases)
Pityriasis Rosea.precautions: avoid scratching affected areas (to prevent skin irritation and infection), take lukewarm baths with oatmeal or baking soda, moisturize the skin, avoid harsh soaps and detergents
Pityriasis Rosea.drugs: antihistamines (such as loratadine or cetirizine) for itching, topical corticosteroids (for severe itching or inflammation), phototherapy (in some cases)
Pityriasis Rosea.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, often based on the appearance of the rash (no specific diagnostic test)

Purpura.symptoms: purplish-red spots or patches on the skin (petechiae or ecchymoses), easy or excessive bruising, bleeding gums, nosebleeds, blood in urine or stool, prolonged bleeding from cuts
Purpura.precautions: treat underlying conditions (such as infections or autoimmune diseases), avoid medications that thin the blood (unless necessary), protect against injuries that could lead to bleeding
Purpura.drugs: depends on the underlying cause; may include corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, antiviral medications, antibiotics, platelet transfusions
Purpura.diagnosis: blood tests (complete blood count, blood clotting tests), urine tests, bone marrow biopsy (in some cases)

Polyps.symptoms: often asymptomatic, rectal bleeding (in colorectal polyps), changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain or discomfort, anemia (from chronic bleeding), nasal congestion or discharge (in nasal polyps), sinus infections
Polyps.precautions: screening tests (such as colonoscopy for colorectal polyps), healthy lifestyle choices (such as maintaining a healthy weight and diet), smoking cessation, managing chronic conditions (such as high blood pressure and diabetes)
Polyps.drugs: depends on the type and location of polyps; may include medications (such as nasal corticosteroids for nasal polyps), endoscopic removal, surgical removal
Polyps.diagnosis: visual inspection (endoscopy, colonoscopy), imaging tests (CT scan, MRI, nasal endoscopy), biopsy

Porphyria.symptoms: abdominal pain (often severe), nausea and vomiting, constipation or diarrhea, muscle pain, weakness or paralysis, urine that is reddish-brown in color, photosensitivity (skin reactions upon exposure to sunlight), neurological symptoms (such as seizures, hallucinations)
Porphyria.precautions: avoid triggers (such as certain medications, alcohol, and exposure to sunlight), maintain good hydration, seek medical advice before taking new medications
Porphyria.drugs: depends on the type and severity of porphyria; may include heme therapy, medications to relieve symptoms (such as pain relievers and anti-nausea drugs), glucose or carbohydrate infusions
Porphyria.diagnosis: blood, urine, and stool tests to measure levels of porphyrins and their precursors, genetic testing, imaging tests (such as MRI or CT scan) to assess for complications

PCOD (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome).symptoms: irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth (hirsutism), acne, weight gain, difficulty losing weight, thinning hair or male-pattern baldness, darkening of the skin (acanthosis nigricans), infertility
PCOD (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome).precautions: maintain a healthy weight, exercise regularly, eat a balanced diet, manage insulin resistance (if present), seek medical advice for fertility concerns
PCOD (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome).drugs: oral contraceptives (to regulate menstrual cycles and reduce androgen levels), anti-androgen medications (such as spironolactone), metformin (to improve insulin sensitivity), fertility medications (if trying to conceive)
PCOD (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome).diagnosis: medical history and physical examination, blood tests (to measure hormone levels), ultrasound (to visualize the ovaries and assess for cysts)

Perimenopause.symptoms: irregular menstrual periods, hot flashes, night sweats, sleep problems, mood swings, vaginal dryness, decreased libido, weight gain, thinning hair or hair loss
Perimenopause.precautions: maintain a healthy lifestyle (including diet, exercise, and stress management), use hormone replacement therapy (if needed and appropriate), seek medical advice for symptom management
Perimenopause.drugs: hormone replacement therapy (estrogen or estrogen-progestin combinations), antidepressants (for mood swings and depression), vaginal lubricants or moisturizers, low-dose oral contraceptives
Perimenopause.diagnosis: medical history and physical examination, blood tests (to measure hormone levels), assessment of symptoms

Psoriatic Arthritis.symptoms: joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, especially in the fingers and toes, nail changes (such as pitting or separation from the nail bed), skin symptoms of psoriasis (such as red, scaly patches), fatigue
Psoriatic Arthritis.precautions: maintain a healthy weight, exercise regularly, protect your joints, avoid smoking, manage stress, seek early treatment to prevent joint damage
Psoriatic Arthritis.drugs: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), biologic agents (such as TNF inhibitors), corticosteroid injections
Psoriatic Arthritis.diagnosis: medical history and physical examination, imaging tests (X-rays, MRI, ultrasound), blood tests (to detect inflammation and antibodies)

Pertussis.symptoms: severe coughing fits (often with a 'whooping' sound), runny nose, nasal congestion, sneezing, low-grade fever, coughing that worsens at night, vomiting after coughing fits (especially in infants)
Pertussis.precautions: get vaccinated (DTaP for infants, Tdap for adolescents and adults), practice good respiratory hygiene (cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing), avoid close contact with infected individuals, stay home when sick
Pertussis.drugs: antibiotics (such as azithromycin, erythromycin) to shorten the duration of illness and reduce spread to others
Pertussis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, laboratory tests (PCR or culture of nasal secretions)

Peyronie's Disease.symptoms: penile curvature (usually upward), penile pain, penile plaques or lumps, erectile dysfunction, shortening of the penis, difficulty with intercourse
Peyronie's Disease.precautions: maintain overall good health, avoid injury to the penis, use caution during sexual activity, discuss treatment options and risks with a healthcare provider
Peyronie's Disease.drugs: collagenase clostridium histolyticum (Xiaflex) injections, oral medications (such as pentoxifylline, tamoxifen), topical verapamil, penile traction therapy
Peyronie's Disease.diagnosis: physical examination, medical history, imaging tests (ultrasound)

Ringworm Infection.symptoms: red, scaly, or raised patches on the skin, itching, blister-like lesions, hair loss in affected areas, nails becoming discolored, thickened, or brittle (in nail infections)
Ringworm Infection.precautions: practice good hygiene (regular handwashing), avoid sharing personal items (such as clothing, towels, combs), keep skin clean and dry, avoid contact with infected animals
Ringworm Infection.drugs: antifungal creams or ointments (such as clotrimazole, terbinafine), oral antifungal medications (in severe cases), medicated shampoos (for scalp infections)
Ringworm Infection.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, skin scraping for microscopic examination (KOH test), fungal culture

Rickets.symptoms: soft or weak bones, delayed growth, skeletal deformities (such as bowlegs or knock knees), dental problems (such as delayed tooth formation or enamel defects), muscle weakness, bone pain or tenderness
Rickets.precautions: ensure adequate vitamin D intake (through diet, supplements, and sunlight exposure), consume sufficient dietary calcium and phosphorus, maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise
Rickets.drugs: vitamin D supplements (ergocalciferol, cholecalciferol), calcium and phosphorus supplements (if deficient), treatment of underlying conditions causing malabsorption
Rickets.diagnosis: blood tests (to measure levels of vitamin D, calcium, phosphorus, and alkaline phosphatase), X-rays (to assess bone density and structure)

Rheumatic Fever.symptoms: fever, joint pain and swelling (especially in larger joints like knees, elbows), chest pain, shortness of breath, skin rash (erythema marginatum), nodules under the skin, jerky body movements (Sydenham's chorea), fatigue
Rheumatic Fever.precautions: prompt treatment of streptococcal throat infections (with antibiotics), regular medical follow-ups, prophylactic antibiotics to prevent recurrent streptococcal infections in high-risk individuals
Rheumatic Fever.drugs: antibiotics (such as penicillin or erythromycin) to treat streptococcal infections, anti-inflammatory medications (such as aspirin or corticosteroids) to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms
Rheumatic Fever.diagnosis: medical history (including recent streptococcal infection), physical examination, blood tests (to detect antibodies against streptococcal bacteria), electrocardiogram (ECG) to assess heart function

Restless Legs Syndrome.symptoms: unpleasant sensations in the legs (often described as creeping, crawling, itching, or tingling), urge to move legs to relieve discomfort (worsens at rest or in the evening), difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep
Restless Legs Syndrome.precautions: maintain a regular sleep schedule, avoid caffeine and alcohol before bedtime, practice relaxation techniques, moderate exercise, massage or stretching before bedtime
Restless Legs Syndrome.drugs: dopamine agonists (such as pramipexole, ropinirole), alpha-2 delta ligands (such as gabapentin, pregabalin), opioids (in severe cases), iron supplements (if iron deficiency is present)
Restless Legs Syndrome.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, medical history, assessment of symptoms according to established diagnostic criteria

Reiter's Syndrome.symptoms: joint pain, swelling, and stiffness (especially in the knees, ankles, and feet), urinary symptoms (such as pain or burning during urination), eye inflammation (conjunctivitis), skin rash (often on the palms, soles, or trunk), mouth ulcers
Reiter's Syndrome.precautions: treat underlying infections promptly, practice safe sex to prevent sexually transmitted infections, maintain good hygiene, avoid smoking
Reiter's Syndrome.drugs: NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen, naproxen) for pain and inflammation, corticosteroids for severe inflammation, antibiotics (if bacterial infection is present)
Reiter's Syndrome.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (to detect markers of inflammation), joint fluid analysis, imaging tests (such as X-rays)

Rubella.symptoms: mild fever, rash (starting on the face and spreading to the body), sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, headache, red eyes (conjunctivitis), swollen lymph nodes
Rubella.precautions: get vaccinated (MMR vaccine), practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals (especially during pregnancy), avoid sharing personal items
Rubella.drugs: mainly supportive care for symptoms, such as fever reducers and pain relievers
Rubella.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (to detect rubella antibodies), viral culture or PCR test of throat swab or urine

Scabies.symptoms: intense itching (especially at night), rash (small red bumps, blisters, or pimple-like bumps), thin, irregular burrow tracks made by the mites (especially between fingers, on wrists, elbows, armpits, or genitals), sores (from scratching)
Scabies.precautions: treat all household members and close contacts simultaneously, wash bedding, clothing, and towels in hot water, vacuum carpets and furniture, avoid close contact with infected individuals
Scabies.drugs: topical scabicides (such as permethrin cream or lotion, or ivermectin cream), oral medications (such as ivermectin pills), antihistamines (for itching)
Scabies.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, skin scraping (microscopic examination of mite, eggs, or fecal matter), sometimes skin biopsy

Syphilis.symptoms: primary stage: painless sore (chancre) at the site of infection (genitals, mouth, or anus); secondary stage: rash on palms and soles, flu-like symptoms, swollen lymph nodes, sore throat; latent stage: no symptoms; tertiary stage: severe damage to internal organs, including the brain, nerves, eyes, heart, blood vessels, liver, bones, and joints
Syphilis.precautions: practice safe sex (use condoms), get tested regularly for sexually transmitted infections, avoid sharing needles or drug paraphernalia, avoid intimate contact with untreated syphilis sores
Syphilis.drugs: antibiotics (usually penicillin, but other antibiotics may be used in allergic individuals or in late-stage disease)
Syphilis.diagnosis: blood tests (such as RPR or VDRL tests), dark-field microscopy of syphilis sore fluid, tissue biopsy (in some cases)

Sepsis.symptoms: fever, elevated heart rate, elevated respiratory rate, confusion or disorientation, shortness of breath, decreased urine output, abnormal white blood cell count, low blood pressure, organ dysfunction
Sepsis.precautions: prevent infections (practice good hygiene, get vaccinated, treat infections promptly), recognize and treat infections early, manage chronic conditions, maintain a healthy lifestyle
Sepsis.drugs: antibiotics (for bacterial infections), intravenous fluids, vasopressors (to raise blood pressure), corticosteroids (in some cases), insulin (to control blood sugar levels)
Sepsis.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect infection and assess organ function), imaging tests (such as X-rays or CT scans), cultures of blood, urine, or other body fluids

Strep Throat.symptoms: sore throat, difficulty swallowing, fever, swollen and tender lymph nodes, red and swollen tonsils, white patches or streaks of pus on the tonsils, headache, rash, stomachache (especially in children)
Strep Throat.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals, cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, avoid sharing utensils or drinks
Strep Throat.drugs: antibiotics (such as penicillin or amoxicillin), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), throat lozenges or sprays
Strep Throat.diagnosis: rapid strep test, throat culture (if rapid test is negative but symptoms persist)

Spondylosis.symptoms: neck or back pain, stiffness, decreased range of motion, muscle weakness or numbness, radiating pain or tingling sensation in the arms or legs (if nerves are compressed)
Spondylosis.precautions: maintain good posture, avoid prolonged sitting or standing, engage in regular exercise to strengthen muscles and improve flexibility, use proper lifting techniques
Spondylosis.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen, NSAIDs), muscle relaxants, corticosteroid injections (for severe pain and inflammation)
Spondylosis.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, imaging tests (X-rays, MRI, CT scans), nerve conduction studies, electromyography (EMG)

Sickle Cell Anemia.symptoms: anemia (fatigue, weakness, pale skin), pain episodes (sudden and severe pain in various body parts), swelling of hands and feet, frequent infections, delayed growth or puberty, vision problems, jaundice, abdominal swelling
Sickle Cell Anemia.precautions: get regular check-ups and screenings, stay hydrated, avoid extreme temperatures, manage pain and infections promptly, avoid overexertion
Sickle Cell Anemia.drugs: pain relievers (such as acetaminophen, NSAIDs), hydroxyurea (to reduce pain episodes), antibiotics (to prevent infections), blood transfusions (in severe cases), bone marrow transplant (in select cases)
Sickle Cell Anemia.diagnosis: blood tests (hemoglobin electrophoresis, complete blood count), newborn screening, family history, genetic testing

STD.symptoms: varies depending on the specific STD, but may include genital sores or ulcers, pain or burning during urination, unusual discharge from the penis or vagina, itching or irritation in the genital area, pelvic pain, abnormal vaginal bleeding, swollen lymph nodes
STD.precautions: practice safe sex (use condoms correctly and consistently), limit sexual partners, get tested regularly for STDs, avoid sharing needles or drug paraphernalia
STD.drugs: antibiotics (for bacterial STDs such as chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis), antiviral medications (for viral STDs such as herpes and HIV), supportive care for symptoms
STD.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, laboratory tests (such as blood tests, urine tests, swabs of genital sores or discharge)

Scleroderma.symptoms: hardening and tightening of the skin, Raynaud's phenomenon (fingers and toes turn white or blue in response to cold or stress), swollen fingers or hands, joint pain, digestive problems, shortness of breath, dry cough, fatigue, weight loss
Scleroderma.precautions: avoid exposure to cold and stress (to reduce Raynaud's attacks), protect skin from injury, maintain flexibility and range of motion with exercise, eat a balanced diet, avoid smoking
Scleroderma.drugs: depends on the symptoms and complications; may include medications to dilate blood vessels (such as calcium channel blockers), immunosuppressants, proton pump inhibitors (for acid reflux), pain relievers, corticosteroids
Scleroderma.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (to detect specific antibodies), skin biopsy, imaging tests (such as X-rays, CT scans)

Scurvy.symptoms: fatigue, weakness, swollen, bleeding gums, joint pain, shortness of breath, easy bruising, dry and scaly skin, hair and tooth loss, swollen or painful joints
Scurvy.precautions: consume foods rich in vitamin C (such as citrus fruits, strawberries, kiwi, bell peppers), avoid excessive consumption of foods that reduce vitamin C absorption (such as alcohol and caffeine), seek medical attention if symptoms persist
Scurvy.drugs: vitamin C supplements, intravenous vitamin C (in severe cases), supportive care for symptoms
Scurvy.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, blood tests (to measure vitamin C levels)

Swine Flu.symptoms: fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, fatigue, diarrhea, vomiting
Swine Flu.precautions: get vaccinated, practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with sick individuals, cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, stay home if infected
Swine Flu.drugs: antiviral medications (such as oseltamivir or zanamivir), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), plenty of fluids, rest
Swine Flu.diagnosis: rapid influenza diagnostic tests (RIDTs), reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) testing, viral culture

Scarlet Fever.symptoms: red rash (feels like sandpaper), red lines in the folds of the body, flushed face, strawberry tongue, high fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, headache, nausea or vomiting
Scarlet Fever.precautions: practice good hand hygiene, avoid close contact with infected individuals, cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, wash utensils and linens used by infected individuals
Scarlet Fever.drugs: antibiotics (such as penicillin or amoxicillin), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), fluids, rest
Scarlet Fever.diagnosis: throat swab (to test for streptococcus bacteria), rapid antigen detection test (RADT), blood tests (if necessary)

Scalp Psoriasis.symptoms: red, inflamed patches of skin, silvery-white scales, dry scalp, itching, burning or soreness, hair loss (due to scratching or treatment)
Scalp Psoriasis.precautions: avoid triggers (such as stress, smoking, and excessive alcohol consumption), keep scalp moisturized, use gentle hair care products, avoid scratching the scalp
Scalp Psoriasis.drugs: topical treatments (such as corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, coal tar, salicylic acid), phototherapy, systemic medications (such as methotrexate, cyclosporine, biologics)
Scalp Psoriasis.diagnosis: physical examination, skin biopsy (if necessary), medical history

Salmonella.symptoms: diarrhea, fever, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, headache, muscle pain
Salmonella.precautions: practice good food hygiene (proper cooking and food handling), avoid consuming raw or undercooked eggs and meat, wash hands thoroughly after handling raw foods, avoid cross-contamination in the kitchen
Salmonella.drugs: rehydration (oral or intravenous fluids), antibiotics (for severe cases), anti-diarrheal medications (with caution)
Salmonella.diagnosis: stool culture, blood tests, imaging tests (if complications are suspected)

Swimmer's Ear.symptoms: itching in the ear canal, redness inside the ear, discomfort or pain (especially when touching the ear), drainage of fluid (clear, pus, or bloody), decreased hearing, feeling of fullness in the ear
Swimmer's Ear.precautions: keep ears dry, use earplugs while swimming, dry ears thoroughly after exposure to water, avoid inserting objects into ears, avoid using non-prescribed ear drops
Swimmer's Ear.drugs: ear drops (antibiotics and steroids), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), keep the ear dry and avoid water activities
Swimmer's Ear.diagnosis: physical examination of the ear, ear swab (for culture and sensitivity)

Sciatica.symptoms: pain radiating from the lower back to the buttock and down the back of the leg, numbness or tingling in the leg, muscle weakness in the affected leg, pain that worsens with movement
Sciatica.precautions: maintain good posture, use proper body mechanics when lifting, maintain a healthy weight, exercise regularly to strengthen the back and core muscles, avoid prolonged sitting or standing
Sciatica.drugs: pain relievers (such as NSAIDs, acetaminophen), muscle relaxants, physical therapy, corticosteroid injections (in some cases), surgical intervention (if severe)
Sciatica.diagnosis: physical examination, MRI or CT scan, X-rays, electromyography (EMG)

Scoliosis.symptoms: uneven shoulders, one shoulder blade more prominent, uneven waist, one hip higher than the other, back pain, difficulty breathing (in severe cases)
Scoliosis.precautions: regular monitoring of spine curvature, physical therapy, maintaining a healthy weight, using supportive seating and sleeping arrangements
Scoliosis.drugs: pain relievers (such as NSAIDs), bracing (for children and adolescents), physical therapy, surgical intervention (for severe cases)
Scoliosis.diagnosis: physical examination, X-rays, MRI or CT scan (in some cases), scoliometer (to measure the degree of curvature)

Smallpox.symptoms: high fever, fatigue, severe headache, back pain, rash (starting as flat red spots, then turning into pus-filled sores), vomiting, abdominal pain
Smallpox.precautions: vaccination (for those at risk), isolate infected individuals, practice good hygiene, use protective clothing and equipment for healthcare workers
Smallpox.drugs: no specific treatment (mainly supportive care), antiviral medications (such as cidofovir, brincidofovir, or tecovirimat in experimental cases), fluids, pain relievers
Smallpox.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, electron microscopy of lesion samples, PCR testing, virus culture

Spinal Stenosis.symptoms: pain or cramping in the legs (especially when standing or walking), lower back pain, numbness or tingling in the legs, weakness in the legs, difficulty maintaining balance
Spinal Stenosis.precautions: maintain a healthy weight, regular exercise to strengthen back and core muscles, use proper body mechanics, avoid high-impact activities
Spinal Stenosis.drugs: pain relievers (such as NSAIDs, acetaminophen), corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, muscle relaxants, surgical intervention (for severe cases)
Spinal Stenosis.diagnosis: physical examination, MRI or CT scan, X-rays, myelogram (in some cases)

Typhoid.symptoms: high fever, headache, abdominal pain, constipation or diarrhea, fatigue, weakness, rash (rose-colored spots), loss of appetite, cough
Typhoid.precautions: drink safe water, practice good hand hygiene, avoid raw fruits and vegetables, get vaccinated (for travelers to endemic areas), avoid risky foods and drinks
Typhoid.drugs: antibiotics (such as ciprofloxacin, azithromycin), rehydration therapy, fever reducers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen)
Typhoid.diagnosis: blood culture, stool culture, urine culture, Widal test

Thalassemia.symptoms: fatigue, weakness, pale or yellowish skin, facial bone deformities, slow growth, abdominal swelling, dark urine, shortness of breath, heart complications
Thalassemia.precautions: genetic counseling, avoid iron-rich foods and supplements, maintain regular medical check-ups, avoid infections through good hygiene, monitor for complications
Thalassemia.drugs: blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy, folic acid supplements, bone marrow transplant (in severe cases)
Thalassemia.diagnosis: complete blood count (CBC), hemoglobin electrophoresis, genetic testing

Tuberculosis.symptoms: persistent cough (lasting more than 3 weeks), coughing up blood, chest pain, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, fever, night sweats, chills, loss of appetite
Tuberculosis.precautions: avoid close contact with infected individuals, ensure proper ventilation, wear masks in high-risk areas, get vaccinated (BCG vaccine), adhere to treatment regimens if infected
Tuberculosis.drugs: antibiotics (such as isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, pyrazinamide), directly observed therapy (DOT) for adherence
Tuberculosis.diagnosis: chest X-ray, sputum test, tuberculin skin test (TST), interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs)

Type 2 Diabetes.symptoms: increased thirst, frequent urination, excessive hunger, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, blurred vision, slow-healing sores, frequent infections, numbness or tingling in the hands or feet
Type 2 Diabetes.precautions: maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet, exercise regularly, monitor blood sugar levels, avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
Type 2 Diabetes.drugs: metformin, sulfonylureas, insulin therapy, DPP-4 inhibitors, SGLT2 inhibitors
Type 2 Diabetes.diagnosis: fasting blood sugar test, HbA1c test, oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), random blood sugar test

Throat Cancer.symptoms: persistent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, ear pain, lump or mass in the neck, weight loss, persistent cough, difficulty breathing
Throat Cancer.precautions: avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption, practice good oral hygiene, maintain a healthy diet, get vaccinated against HPV, regular medical check-ups
Throat Cancer.drugs: surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy
Throat Cancer.diagnosis: laryngoscopy, biopsy, imaging tests (such as CT scan, MRI, PET scan)

Tetanus.symptoms: muscle stiffness and spasms (starting in the jaw), difficulty swallowing, fever, sweating, high blood pressure, rapid heart rate, muscle pain
Tetanus.precautions: get vaccinated (tetanus toxoid vaccine), clean wounds thoroughly, seek medical care for deep or dirty wounds, use proper wound care techniques
Tetanus.drugs: tetanus immunoglobulin, antibiotics (such as metronidazole), muscle relaxants, wound care, supportive care
Tetanus.diagnosis: clinical evaluation, no specific lab test (based on symptoms and wound history)

Thrombophlebitis.symptoms: pain, tenderness, redness, and swelling along the course of the affected vein, warmth of the skin over the area, hardening of the vein, fever (if infection is present)
Thrombophlebitis.precautions: avoid prolonged immobility, stay hydrated, maintain a healthy weight, avoid smoking, wear compression stockings if at risk
Thrombophlebitis.drugs: anticoagulants (such as heparin, warfarin), NSAIDs for pain, antibiotics (if infection is present), thrombolytic therapy (in severe cases)

Trigeminal Neuralgia.symptoms: severe, shooting or jabbing pain (like an electric shock), pain triggered by touching the face, chewing, speaking or brushing teeth, bouts of pain lasting from a few seconds to several minutes, pain occurring in cycles
Trigeminal Neuralgia.precautions: identify and avoid triggers, maintain good oral hygiene, regular dental check-ups, stress management, consider dietary changes
Trigeminal Neuralgia.drugs: anticonvulsants (such as carbamazepine, gabapentin), muscle relaxants, tricyclic antidepressants, surgery (microvascular decompression or gamma knife surgery)

Tetralogy of Fallot.symptoms: cyanosis (blue skin coloration), shortness of breath, fainting, clubbing of fingers and toes, poor weight gain, irritability, prolonged crying, heart murmur
Tetralogy of Fallot.precautions: regular medical follow-up, avoid smoking and alcohol during pregnancy (to prevent congenital defects), maintain a healthy lifestyle, follow medical advice for managing symptoms
Tetralogy of Fallot.drugs: surgery (to repair the heart defects), medications to manage symptoms (such as beta-blockers, diuretics), oxygen therapy (if needed)
Tetralogy of Fallot.diagnosis: echocardiogram, chest X-ray, ECG, cardiac catheterization

Toxoplasmosis.symptoms: flu-like symptoms (such as body aches, swollen lymph nodes, headache, fever, fatigue), blurred vision, confusion (if severe), seizures (if severe), poor coordination (if severe)
Toxoplasmosis.precautions: avoid eating undercooked meat, wash hands thoroughly after handling raw meat or soil, avoid changing cat litter (or wear gloves), practice good hygiene
Toxoplasmosis.drugs: antiparasitic medications (such as pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine), folinic acid (to counteract side effects of medications), supportive care
Toxoplasmosis.diagnosis: blood tests (to detect antibodies), amniocentesis (if pregnant), imaging tests (such as MRI, CT scan)

Tendinitis.symptoms: pain at the site of the tendon and surrounding area, tenderness, mild swelling, difficulty moving the affected joint, stiffness, weakness
Tendinitis.precautions: avoid repetitive strain on tendons, use proper technique in sports or activities, warm up before exercise, strengthen muscles around tendons, take breaks and rest when needed
Tendinitis.drugs: NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen, naproxen), corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, pain relievers, rest and ice
Tendinitis.diagnosis: physical examination, imaging tests (such as ultrasound, MRI), medical history

Thrombosis.symptoms: swelling in one leg (or arm), pain or tenderness in the affected area, warmth and redness over the affected vein, leg cramps (often starting in the calf), unexplained shortness of breath (if the clot travels to the lungs)
Thrombosis.precautions: avoid prolonged immobility, stay hydrated, maintain a healthy weight, avoid smoking, wear compression stockings if at risk
Thrombosis.drugs: anticoagulants (such as heparin, warfarin, DOACs), thrombolytic therapy (in severe cases), pain relievers, compression stockings
Thrombosis.diagnosis: ultrasound, blood tests (D-dimer), venography, CT or MRI (if pulmonary embolism is suspected)

Tapeworm Infection.symptoms: abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, loss of appetite, weight loss, fatigue, weakness, vitamin and mineral deficiencies
Tapeworm Infection.precautions: cook meat and fish thoroughly, practice good hand hygiene, wash fruits and vegetables, avoid consuming raw or undercooked pork, beef, or fish
Tapeworm Infection.drugs: antiparasitic medications (such as praziquantel, albendazole), supportive care (such as rehydration therapy), nutritional supplements (if deficiencies are present)
Tapeworm Infection.diagnosis: stool examination, blood tests (for antibodies), imaging tests (such as X-rays, CT scan, MRI)

Tennis Elbow.symptoms: pain and tenderness on the outer part of the elbow, weakened grip strength, pain when lifting or bending the arm, pain when gripping small objects, pain when twisting the forearm
Tennis Elbow.precautions: avoid repetitive wrist and elbow movements, use proper equipment and technique in sports, strengthen the forearm muscles, use a brace or strap during activities, apply ice to the affected area after activity
Tennis Elbow.drugs: NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen or naproxen), corticosteroid injections (for severe pain), physical therapy, topical pain relievers
Tennis Elbow.diagnosis: physical examination, imaging tests (such as MRI or ultrasound), X-rays (to rule out other conditions)

Thyroid Disease.symptoms: fatigue, weight changes, dry skin, hair loss, sensitivity to cold or heat, muscle weakness, irregular menstrual cycles, changes in heart rate
